headline: Everyday I Will Move Forward But I Will Never Move On
authors: Kaitlin Roig-DeBellis, ContributorFounder, Classes 4 Classes, Author & Speaker
short descr: This time leading up to December 14th, specifically the weeks after Thanksgiving, is always a bit harder than every other day. I have found over the past 3 years, 11 months and 17 days that when something horrible happens in your life it becomes wholly a part of you.
image_caption(s): FILE - In this Jan. 14, 2013 file photo, white roses with the faces of victims of the Sandy Hook Elementary School shooting are attached to a telephone pole near the school on the one-month anniversary of the shooting that left 26 dead in Newtown, Conn. Some Newtown families have said they were given a voice late in the process of dispersing the millions of dollars in donated funds, and that the process has been bureaucratic, difficult, unpleasant, and has added to their pain. (AP Photo/Jessica Hill, File)
article: This time leading up to December 14th, specifically the weeks after Thanksgiving, is always a bit harder than every other day. It is a real reminder of what could have easily been our last days, weeks-a reminder that it was for 26 precious lives. It's a reminder that so much was permanently, inextricably, forever, changed. Everyday of my life I will move forward. I will never move on. I have found over the past 3 years, 11 months and 17 days that when something horrible happens in your life it becomes wholly a part of you. So deeply ingrained like the ring a coffee cup makes on a table, or the crack in a bone after it has been broken-it is, you are, never the same. And so, you move forward-but you don't move on. You don't move on because you can't. Because what has happened becomes every second of every minute of every single day. But you do move forward, and if you are lucky you do so in a way that actually strengthens and bolsters you because you come to realize that you are able to move forward in spite of it, in the face of it-regardless of the fact that it consumes every ounce of your being. That's when you realize how powerful you are. You are still standing, breathing, loving, growing, hoping. You. Still. Are.And that's when you learn that life is not the things that knock us down. It's not the moments that literally take our breath away. It's not the moments where we are sure we will not be able to go on. Instead it's the moment(s) after. Where we come to realize that the darkness, the loss, the deep void-is not what defines us. But that it is how we choose to react. The choice to move forward, not on. We can each make that choice for ourselves to decide that the things that happen to us, do not have to define us.

headline: North Carolina NAACP Fights Back Against Lawsuit Disenfranchising Black Voters
short descr: The Civitas Institute is waging a war against same-day registration.
image_caption(s): The Rev. William Barber holds a press conference in Raleigh, North Carolina, discussing voting rights and voter suppression in the 2016 election, on Oct. 28, 2016.
article: WASHINGTON â€• The North Carolina NAACP said Friday it will file a motion to dismiss a lawsuit that would potentially allow Gov. Pat McCrory (R), who has been fighting to maintain the stateâ€™s highest office, to further draw out the 2016 election process.Francis De Luca, the president of the conservative think-tank Civitas Institute, filed a federal lawsuit on Nov. 22 against North Carolinaâ€™s Board of Elections, asking that election results not be certified until 90,000 voters who registered on the same day they voted have their addresses verified.De Lucaâ€™s lawsuit asks for an immediate injunction that would stop votes from being counted, claiming county election boards didnâ€™t have enough time to verify same-day registrantsâ€™ addresses. Such a halt would stop the state from being able to announce the official outcome of the election until Dec. 7. While thatâ€™s only a few days away, the North Carolina NAACP wants the counting to continue because it sees the lawsuit as an attack on black voters, who are more likely to use same-day registration in North Carolina.â€œThe De Luca plaintiff is doing no more than beating a dead horse, and unnecessarily, to extend the voting count in North Carolina,â€ said Irving Joyner, the legal counsel for the North Carolina NAACP, during a press call on Friday. North Carolina Attorney General Roy Cooper (D) declared victory over McCrory on Nov. 9 following a tight race. But McCrory did not concede, claiming the race was too close to call.Since then, McCrory has requested that more than 60,000 provisional and absentee ballots â€• most of which were filed in Democratic strongholds â€• be counted, filed for a statewide recount and logged election protests in 52 counties accusing dead people and felons of voting. A portion of his protests were dismissed, and on Dec. 1, Cooperâ€™s lead over McCrory passed 10,000 votes, the threshold at which a candidate can request a statewide recount. Itâ€™s unclear whether the 90,000 votes being challenged by De Luca would help McCrory.De Luca and the Civitas Institute are in favor of eliminating same-day registration and requiring voters to have an ID, two rules implemented by North Carolinaâ€™s voter ID law in 2013. A federal appeals court struck down the law in July, after judges determined that Republican lawmakers in the state mandated specific ID requirements, shortened the early voting period and changed registration procedures in order to suppress black voters.The Rev. William Barber, the president of the North Carolina NAACP, said conservative efforts to challenge the election are ironic considering â€œthey have been found guilty numerous times in the federal courts of engaging in voter suppression, voter schemes and race-based quota denial.â€â€œNow theyâ€™re trying to suggest and project onto others their own guilt. They ran this election and theyâ€™re saying â€• it would be laughable if it wasnâ€™t so serious â€• that they suppressed themselves,â€ he said.The current case is similar to another legal battle the North Carolina NAACP won in November. In that case, election officials in Beaufort, Moore and Cumberland Counties canceled voter registrations after mailers sent to voter addresses were returned as undeliverable. The North Carolina NAACP sued in response, claiming many of the voters still lived at the addresses on their registrations or had simply moved within the same county, allowing them to still vote there. The civil rights group said the cancelations were an attempt to suppress the black vote. U.S. District Judge Loretta Biggs, who called the stateâ€™s process for challenging voter registrations â€œinsane,â€ ordered county election boards to restore the registrations on Nov. 4.CORRECTION: A previous version of this story said De Lucaâ€™s lawsuit targeted voters who registered on Election Day; the suit focused on voters who registered during an early voting period.Related Coverage:Hereâ€™s A Look Inside Election Protection Efforts In North Carolina

headline: Florida Atheist Sets Up Anti-Trump Festivus Pole At City's Christmas Display
short descr: "This yearâ€™s pole is shorter, a shout-out to Donaldâ€™s tiny hands."
image_caption(s): The anti-Trump "Distresstivus" Pole in Deerfield Beach, Florida.
article: Donald Trump is already getting some Christmas jeer. Florida atheist and First Amendment activist Chaz Stevens has made the president-elect the subject of his â€œDistresstivusâ€ Pole, placed next to a Nativity scene on city property in Deerfield Beach.Thatâ€™s his version of a Festivus pole, the centerpiece of the secular holiday celebrated on Seinfeld known for its â€œairing of the grievances.â€And when it comes to Trump, Stevens â€• founder of the Religious Liberty Project â€• has plenty of grievances.â€œWrapped with an upside-down American flag (acknowledging the majority of Americans who didnâ€™t vote for the Pumpkin In Chief), this yearâ€™s pole is shorter, a shout-out to Donaldâ€™s tiny hands,â€ Stevens said via email. â€œWeâ€™ve donned Distresstivus with the infamous Make America Great Again red cap, and fastened it all together with a big olâ€™ safety pin.â€He is hoping to eventually burn the display and has applied for a fire permit from the city, but said he hasnâ€™t heard back. Stevens has trolled Trump before. Earlier this year, members of his group wore a giant penis costume with Trumpâ€™s face as they crashed rallies.But itâ€™s the holiday displays that have gained him national fame â€• which may be ironic since his initial goal wasnâ€™t to create a holiday scene, but to have the Nativity display in Deerfield Beach removed on First Amendment grounds.When the city refused, Stevens took a different tack and instead pushed for the inclusion of his own seasonal message â€• choosing Festivus, with the pole each year themed to a topical issue.â€œI thought, â€˜If you canâ€™t beat â€˜em, join â€˜em,â€ Stevens told the Sun Sentinel last year, when he erected a rainbow-striped pole topped with a disco ball in celebration of gay rights. Last yearâ€™s poles were set up in at least five states, in capitol buildings and other public locations where governments have allowed Nativity scenes and other religious symbols. This year, Stevens has a pole going up in Delray Beach, also in Florida â€• the third time it has been placed there â€• along with the one in Deerfield Beach. â€œAdditionally, weâ€™re returning late this month to the Florida State Capitol rotunda, planting Distresstivus right down the hall from Gov. Skeletorâ€™s office,â€ he said, referring to Florida Gov. Rick Scott. Stevens has eight poles ready to go. Supporters who want to see them erected around the country can contribute to the Religious Liberty Project.

headline: Donald Trump Sold His Investment In Carrierâ€™s Parent Company, Transition Team Says
short descr: Trump negotiated the jobs deal with Carrier months later, a spokeswoman said.
image_caption(s): President-elect Donald Trump and Vice President-elect Mike Pence wave as they visit the Carrier factory on Dec. 1, 2016, in Indianapolis, Indiana.
article: President-elect Donald Trump sold bonds issued by Carrier Corporationâ€™s parent company, United Technologies, in January, according to Trumpâ€™s presidential transition team. Hope Hicks, the spokeswoman for the transition team who informed The Huffington Post that Trump made the sale, did not address a request to provide documentation of it.Barring additional information, it is impossible to verify the Trump transition teamâ€™s claim until the president-electâ€™s next financial disclosure in May 2017, which will show asset sales made in 2016. Trump earned $2,501 to $5,000 in interest income from bonds issued by Carrierâ€™s parent company, United Technologies Inc., according to Trumpâ€™s May financial disclosure. That disclosure only shows income and asset sales for the previous calendar year. The Indy Star first reported Trumpâ€™s stake in the company. Had Trump not made the sale, he would have had a modest financial stake in the health of Carrier, the company with which he just negotiated a deal to keep 800 manufacturing jobs in the United States.Although Trump treated Carrier as a whipping post during the campaign, now that he has finalized a deal he has spoken about the company favorably, generating it positive national media attention.A Carrier spokeswoman declined to comment on the matter.Trump is already drawing pressure from ethics experts and congressional Democrats who are calling on him to divest from his myriad global businesses, including the Trump International Hotel in Washington, D.C., which foreign governments are already patronizing as a way to curry favor with the incoming administration. headline: Senate Democrat Urges Obama To Ensure The CIA Torture Report Won't Disappear
short descr: Ron Wyden is worried the report could be destroyed under the Trump administration if it's not made a federal record.
image_caption(s): The CIA torture report, an â€œexhaustive history with hundreds of footnotes,â€ should â€œat a minimumâ€ be protected by becoming federal record, said Sen. Ron Wyden (D-Ore.). President-elect Donald Trump promised during his campaign to "bring back a hell of a lot worse than waterboarding.â€
article: WASHINGTON â€• If President Barack Obama wants to codify his legacy on banning the use of torture in U.S. intelligence gathering, he should declassify the 6,700-page CIA torture report and make it a federal record, according to a top Senate Democrat. Ron Wyden, a vocal member of the Senate intelligence committee, has long urged the administration to declassify the report with necessary redactions. But now heâ€™s pressuring Obama to make the report a document of federal record before he leaves office â€• protecting it from possible destruction under a Donald Trump presidency. With Trump heading to the White House in just under two months, the Oregon Democrat told The Huffington Post itâ€™s â€œmore important than everâ€ that the American public know what is in the full torture report.Something Obama â€œcan do today on this,â€ Wyden said, is â€œmake sure the report isnâ€™t destroyed and lost to history.â€â€œAll that the president needs to do is direct that the report be a federal record under the Federal Records Act, and an agency record pursuant to [the Freedom of Information Act], and then it can be disseminated widely to appropriate, cleared agencies,â€ Wyden said in his Capitol Hill office on Wednesday.On his second day in office Obama used his executive authority to ban â€œenhanced interrogationâ€ techniques authorized by President George W. Bush, but his administration decided not to press charges against individuals involved in the torture program. Prompted by revelations that the CIA had destroyed videotapes of some of its interrogations, the Senate intelligence committee voted in 2009 to investigate the CIAâ€™s detention and interrogation program. In December 2014, the Democrats on the committee released a 525-page executive summary of their findings. They concluded that the CIAâ€™s interrogation program used techniques far more brutal than it had previously disclosed and misled the public about the efficacy of the program in producing intelligence.The full report remains classified. Lawyers who represent detainees at Guantanamo who were previously held at CIA black sites say the executive summary of the torture report reveals only a small part of the abuse their clients endured. The Obama administration has been less than eager to declassify the report, with agencies directed to keep their copies unopened. Even less transparency is expected from his successor. Trump, a real estate businessman with no prior government experience, said earlier this year that he would â€œbring back a hell of a lot worse than waterboarding.â€ Trumpâ€™s sympathetic stance toward torture is why Wyden thinks the president-elect wouldnâ€™t think twice about the destruction of a report long mired in controversy.â€œIt seems to me â€• and thisâ€™ll be the argument weâ€™d be making to the administration â€• that the president wants a legacy issue,â€ Wyden said. â€œThis is something he can do today that will be very meaningful, and frankly weâ€™re very concerned that itâ€™s just going to get destroyed and that will be that.â€Making the torture report a federal record would not require its declassification, but making it an agency record would open it up to a Freedom of Information Act request. Even then, it can be redacted in part or full. The report, an â€œexhaustive history with hundreds of footnotes,â€ should â€œat a minimumâ€ be protected, Wyden said. He later clarified it has tens of thousands of footnotes.Wyden pointed to Trumpâ€™s campaign promises, the views of those heâ€™s surrounding himself with, and comments made by his Republican colleagues as proof thereâ€™s a real threat the report could be lost forever.In January 2015, during his first month as chairman of the Senate intelligence committee, Sen. Richard Burr (R-N.C.) requested that the White House return every copy of the document that had been distributed to the administration officials and federal agencies. In a letter to Obama, Burr wrote: â€œI consider that report to be a highly classified and committee sensitive document.â€â€œIt should not be entered into any Executive Branch system of records,â€ Burr continued. At the time, Burr also said he planned to give back a critical secret document, the Panetta Review, that underpins the entire Senate investigation into the CIAâ€™s torture program.Burr never got the copies of the torture report back; the White House said it would â€œpreserve the status quo.â€ But once Republicans have complete control of the federal government from the White House on down, it only follows that Burr would again request to have the last copies of the secret report returned. And what he does with them after that is pretty much up to him. That means the fate of the infamous document would depend on individual senators like Wyden fighting to keep it in existence until it can be declassified. Sen. Dianne Feinstein (D-Calif.), who led the intel committee during the investigation and when the report was released, is also pushing for Obama to declassify the document. She hasnâ€™t always been supportive, however. A New Yorker report published in the summer of 2015 said Wyden, then-Sen. Mark Udall (D-Colo.) and Sen. Martin Heinrich (D-N.M.) rarely aligned with Feinstein on surveillance and tried to convince her to push for the entire declassification of the report. â€œFeinstein, concerned that the information in the full report would be too inflammatory, decided that the executive summary sufficed for the time being,â€ according to the New Yorker. Sheâ€™s changed her mind since, and handed a letter to Vice President Joe Biden to give to Obama last week, urging him to make it public. â€œThe time has come to declassify the report, allow the general public to make up its own mind,â€ Feinstein said, according to Politico. At least, those thatâ€™ll read 7,000 pages.â€So far, the White House response has not been encouraging. â€œIt was not a full-throated: â€˜We are gonna declassify the report,â€ Wyden said of recent statements coming from the administration. â€œSo weâ€™ve got some heavy lifting to do on that.â€In the final days of the Obama administration, Wyden says, he plans to focus on preserving the torture report so people understand what the CIA engaged in when interrogating suspected terrorists, and â€œthat itâ€™s contrary to our values; contrary to our laws.â€â€œI want to amp up the concern I have to make sure that this full report is not destroyed,â€ he said. â€œThatâ€™s all the more reason why the report ought to be put in hands of American people so that you can have a real debate about this.â€White House spokesman Ned Price didnâ€™t comment on Obamaâ€™s plans for the report or on calls by Democratic senators for it to be declassified or made a federal record. â€œThe President supported the declassification of the Summary, Findings, and Conclusions of the Senateâ€™s report on detention and interrogation, with appropriate redactions for national security, in part to ensure certain practices were never employed again,â€ Price said. â€œWe also have made clear that U.S. law prohibits torture without exception, and that all U.S. personnel are prohibited from engaging in torture at all times and in all places. Similarly, we reaffirmed our commitment to the Convention Against Torture, and have strongly backed Congressional efforts to codify key interrogation reforms from the Executive Order that the President signed nearly 8 years ago.â€â€œTo be sure, we have owned up to past mistakes and helped to right wrongs â€•both at home and abroad,â€ Price continued. â€œAs the President said in 2014, â€˜No nation is perfect. But one of the strengths that makes America exceptional is our willingness to openly confront our past, face our imperfections, make changes and do better.â€™ That is precisely what we have done and will continue to do.â€When Feinstein disseminated the copies nearly two years ago there were eight: one sent to the White House, two to the CIA (one for the inspector general, which was â€œmistakenlyâ€ deleted) and the rest to five different agencies. The White House declined to comment Thursday on the status of the various copies. Jessica Schulberg contributed reporting.

headline: The House Science Committee Doesn't Seem To Understand The Concept Of Winter
short descr: Why bother NASA when you can get your climate news from Breitbart?
image_caption(s): Rep. Lamar Smith (R-Texas), a noted climate change denier, chairs the House Science Committee.
article: The House of Representativesâ€™ Science Committee sent out a Twitter message Thursday afternoon that appears to mock â€œclimate alarmists,â€ an odd and disconcerting move considering the group is tasked with overseeing the governmentâ€™s role in scientific research.The tweet linked to an article posted on hyper-conservative Breitbart News, which points to the oft-used and completely incorrect assumption that because itâ€™s getting cold out (i.e. winter) the climate canâ€™t be changing.As NASA points out â€• ironically a group the Science Committee oversees â€• weather and climate are two vastly different things: â€œWeather is what conditions of the atmosphere are over a short period of time, and climate is how the atmosphere â€˜behavesâ€™ over relatively long periods of time. When we talk about climate change, we talk about changes in long-term averages of daily weather.â€Scientists almost universally agree that the climate is changing and humans are the primary cause.But even if the House committee were just looking at weather, November was actually particularly warm. Mashableâ€™s Andrew Freedman reports that the ratio of record highs to record lows was a staggering 51-to-1 last month, and 2016 is already expected to be the warmest year in recorded history.Climate scientists took to Twitter to lambast the tweet, as did an apparently livid Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.).The Committee on Science, Space and Technology is chaired by Rep. Lamar Smith (R-Texas), a noted climate change denier with a 7 percent lifetime ranking from the League of Conservation Voters on environmental issues. In recent years, Smith has tried to intimidate and subpoena scientists into submission and has said the landmark Paris climate agreement is based in â€œscience fiction.â€Smith has received more than $693,000 from the oil and gas industry over the course of his career. Thursdayâ€™s tweet wasnâ€™t the first anti-science message posted on the account. Others allege green groups â€œvalue politics and emotion over facts,â€ question countriesâ€™ abilities to meet climate goals and call the Paris climate deal â€œall pain and no gain.â€The Huffington Post has reached out to Smith to see if he has access to the Houseâ€™s Twitter account.Rep. Eddie Bernice Johnson (D-Texas), the ranking member of the committee, said the tweet was â€œpar for the courseâ€ when it comes to the majorityâ€™s actions in Congress.â€œThey attempted to intimidate NOAAâ€™s scientists over climate change research results that they didnâ€™t like, put forth a NASA bill that gutted Earth science, and continuously attacked any effort on the part of the Administration to deal with climate change,â€ Johnson said in a statement to HuffPost. â€œThis is all while those of us in the Minority have continuously sounded the drumbeat on the reality of climate change and the need for investments in clean energy technologies and climate change research and mitigation.â€

headline: Trumpâ€™s Scorched-Earth Win Turns Even A Boring Post-Election Seminar Nasty
short descr: A Harvard Institute of Politics discussion devolved into a shouting match over â€˜Alt-Right,â€™ â€˜Lock Her Upâ€™
image_caption(s): The Harvard Institute of Politics' post-election roundtable turned into a shouting match, as top campaign staff to President-elect Donald Trump and Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton re-litigated the race Thursday evening.
article: Whatâ€™s traditionally a clinical dissection of a presidential race turned every bit as vicious and ugly as this election wound up, with President-elect Donald Trumpâ€™s top campaign staff gloating about their victory Thursday evening and denying any connection to the openly racist Alt-Right movement.â€œIf providing a platform for white supremacists makes me a brilliant tactician, I am glad to have lost,â€ said Jennifer Palmieri, a top aide to Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton, her voice cracking. â€œI would rather lose than win the way you guys did.â€â€œNo, you wouldnâ€™t. No, you wouldnâ€™t,â€ taunted Trumpâ€™s campaign manager, Kellyanne Conway. â€œThatâ€™s very clear to me. No, you wouldnâ€™t. Respectfully.â€â€œYou guys are pathetic,â€ added David Bossie, Trumpâ€™s deputy campaign manager.The Harvard Institute of Politicsâ€™ quadrennial post-election forum is typically a seminar of interest only to political junkies. But Thursdayâ€™s discussion re-litigated the Trump teamâ€™s scorched-earth strategy of promising criminal prosecution of Clinton and showcasing the female accusers of her husband as a way to deflect attention from Trumpâ€™s long history of demeaning women and minorities â€• including audio of him bragging of his ability to grab women by the genitals.The Clinton staffers pointed to Trumpâ€™s decision to bring in Steve Bannon â€• who has boasted that his Breitbart News website had become a platform for white nationalists who call themselves the Alt-Right â€• as the campaignâ€™s CEO in August.That was on top of Trumpâ€™s use of racially charged language at his campaign events, the Clinton staffers said. â€œThere were dog whistles sent out to people,â€ said Clinton pollster Joel Benenson. â€œLook at your rallies. He delivered it.â€â€œYouâ€™re not being nice. Youâ€™re certainly not being analytical,â€ Conway responded.She argued that Trump successfully appealed to voters frustrated with their lack of economic progress in recent years, while Clinton failed to connect with them. â€œHow in the world did we have a female candidate whose closing arguments were so negative?â€ Conway asked. â€œIt was all about Donald Trump. She was obsessed with Donald Trump. Obsessed with calling him a racist, a xenophobe, a homophobe, a sexist. And guess where it got you.â€Clinton had held polling leads over Trump through most of the summer and autumn, but saw her advantage narrow dramatically in the final days of the campaign, when FBI Director James Comey revealed he was looking at additional emails in the probe of Clintonâ€™s private email server. He announced the weekend before the election that the new emails had not changed his earlier decision not to file charges.Trump wound up winning the Electoral College by a healthy margin, but losing the popular vote by 2.5 million. In fact, a swing of fewer than 100,000 votes across three key states would have given the presidency to Clinton.

headline: Unhappy Dog Wearing Pants And Sweater Found Roaming In Park
short descr: He's in a better mood now.

article: A lost dog that police in Washington state picked up this week wasnâ€™t wearing identification â€• but he was wearing pants and a festive sweater.â€œIs this your dog?â€ the Bellevue Police Department tweeted, noting that the pup â€œwas wearing a sweater and blue pants, and was very angry.â€The photo has been retweeted thousands of times and has garnered plenty of theories to explain the dogâ€™s attitude (and to make a few digs at Bellevue, a Seattle suburb thatâ€™s become increasingly wealthy).Police initially brought the dog to VCA Alpine Animal Hospital. headline: Indiana Reporter Barred From Donald Trumpâ€™s Carrier Event

article: When President-elect Donald Trump visited a Carrier Corp. factory in Indianapolis on Thursday that wonâ€™t be closing following his intervention, a journalist who had deeply investigated the companyâ€™s plans to move jobs to Mexico wasnâ€™t permitted inside.The decision appears to have been made by Carrier and not the Trump team, which had regularly denied press credentials to news outlets during the presidential campaign. This year, heâ€™s spoken to dozens of workers and traveled to Monterrey, Mexico, to highlight how the company planned to pay workers there around $3 an hour. headline: Donald Trump Keeps Draining Swamp By Replacing Food Lobbyist With Former Food Lobbyist
short descr: The new head of Trump's agriculture team used to carry water for PepsiCo and DuPont.
image_caption(s): President-elect Donald Trump is well known for his adoration of fast food. But we don't yet know how his administration will approach food policy.
article: We donâ€™t know much about what President-elect Donald Trump plans to do about the many problems â€” like food insecurity, environmental pollution, unsustainable farming practices and obesity â€” facing the U.S. food system.But what we do know so far is cause for alarm to many food advocates.To date, Trump has not announced his pick for the secretary of the U.S. Department of Agriculture. Though various reports have narrowed the list to a half-dozen or so names, the final selection likely wonâ€™t be made for at least another week or two.In the meantime, focus has shifted to the names of the individuals Trump previously tasked to direct the transition of the department as part of his agriculture advisory committee, a group initially headed up by veteran D.C. food and agriculture lobbyist Michael Torrey.Torrey, whose recent clients include Little Caesarâ€™s, the Snack Food Association and the soda-pushing American Beverage Association, abruptly resigned from the post last month after Trump announced a ban on lobbyists serving in the transition effort. Appointed in Torreyâ€™s place was Joel Leftwich, staff director of the Senate Agriculture Committee and a long-time advisor for Senator Pat Roberts (R-Kansas).Leftwich himself is a former lobbyist, having worked for two years as senior director of public policy and government affairs for PepsiCo between 2013 and 2015 and, prior to that, serving for three months as the program manager of federal government affairs at chemical giant DuPont in 2010.Prior to that, Leftwich did work for a year as a congressional liaison to the USDA. (That was between 2004 and 2005, during George W. Bushâ€™s second administration). But the industry ties of Leftwich and many other members of Trumpâ€™s ag advisory committee are alarming, if not surprising, to advocates for a healthy and sustainable food system.They fear that advancements on such issues during the Obama administration could be slowed or reversed altogether in the coming years.Jim Oâ€™Hara, director of health promotion policy at the nonprofit Center for Science in the Public Interest, told The Huffington Post that Leftwichâ€™s background indicates industry interests may be prioritized by Trumpâ€™s USDA. This could mean a rollback of food safety laws or nutrition initiatives.â€œObviously, having pro-industry folks on the transition team who are likely to put in place pro-business policies without balancing public health concerns is an issue of concern,â€ Oâ€™Hara said.Tiffany Finck-Haynes, food futures campaigner at the Friends of the Earth environmental nonprofit, agreed. Leftwichâ€™s close affiliation with Sen. Roberts, the lead opponent to legislation allowing states to approve laws requiring genetically modified foods to be labeled, is alarming, she said.â€œBasically, Trump is replacing a lobbyist with a former lobbyist,â€ Finck-Haynes said. â€œThat indicates to us that he is much more serious about protecting corporate interests than protecting the American public and the environment.â€But other advocates are less concerned with the direction the Trump administrationâ€™s ag appointments appear to be heading.Scott Faber, vice president at the Environmental Working Group, described Leftwichâ€™s past connections to industry as an asset given that many companies, including PepsiCo, are working to better cater their products to consumersâ€™ demand for healthier, more sustainable choices.â€œHe sort of straddles the divide where food companies tend to think the customerâ€™s always right, while many farm lobbyists tend to think the customerâ€™s always wrong,â€ Faber told HuffPost.Further, the revolving door between lobbying and posts like Leftwichâ€™s isnâ€™t particularly unusual â€” and thatâ€™s true of both Democratic and Republican administrations, according to Ferd Hoefner, policy director at the National Sustainable Agriculture Coalition.While representing NSAC on the hill, Hoefner took part in meetings with Leftwich on the Senate Agriculture Committee, on issues like authorizing a farm-to-school program as part of the 2010 Child Nutrition Act. He described the experience as positive.â€œJoel certainly is someone who knows how things work,â€ Hoefner said. â€œHe has a practical side. We may not always agree on positions, but we can certainly easily work together to move things forward.â€Still, it will be too early to know exactly what a Trump administration will mean for our food system until the USDA secretary pick is announced.One apparent front-runner, Texas Agriculture Commissioner Sid Miller, a Republican, has raised eyebrows for both his temperament and food policy positions.Miller called Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton a â€œcuntâ€ on Twitter last month, in a tweet he blamed on an error made by a campaign staffer. And heâ€™s been labeled a â€œking of cupcakes and deep-fried advocateâ€ for his junk food-inclusive approach to school nutrition.Trumpâ€™s selection this week of U.S. Rep. Tom Price (R-Ga.) as secretary of health and human services, the agency that oversees the Food and Drug Administration, has also prompted concerns.As Politico reported Wednesday, Priceâ€™s congressional record includes voting against the Food Safety and Modernization Act and the Healthy Hunger-Free Kids Act. He also opposed menu labeling rules for convenience stores and grocers under the Affordable Care Act.Still, food advocates are pressing on.Regardless of whom the Trump administration selects as agriculture secretary, Tom Colicchio, celebrity chef and co-founder of the food advocacy group Food Policy Action, emphasized that his organization will push them to â€œtake care of the health of our country across the board.â€â€œWe encourage Washington to keep turning the dial forward towards good food policy because that is what consumers want and every American deserves,â€ Colicchio said in an email.â€•-â€•Joseph Erbentraut covers promising innovations and challenges in the areas of food and water. headline: How 'Search Party' Star John Early Made 2016 A Little Bit Brighter
short descr: The queer actor-comedian is just the comic relief we need this year.
image_caption(s): "Search Party" star John Early (center) has been honing his craft on the stand-up comedy circuit for years.
article: 2016 might be marred with tragedy, social injustice and the rise of a cringeworthy president-elect, but on the flip side, itâ€™ll also be known as the year that gave us John Early.That said, the fact that Earlyâ€™s work is only now finding its way into the mainstream is a downright shame. Heâ€™s also brought his signature wit to television in â€œBroad Cityâ€ and â€œWet Hot American Summer: First Day of Camp,â€ and stole scenes on the big screen with small roles in â€œOther Peopleâ€ and â€œNeighbors 2: Sorority Rising.â€But itâ€™s â€œSearch Party,â€ TBSâ€™s binge-worthy new series, thatâ€™s giving Early his well-deserved breakout. The 10-episode comedy-thriller, which premiered Nov. 21 and is available for streaming in its entirety, skewers the type of Brooklyn-dwelling millennial culture of HBOâ€™s â€œGirlsâ€ and tips its hat to the scares of â€œStranger Thingsâ€ while weaving in â€œSerialâ€-style suspense. In the show, the Tennessee native stars as Elliott, a sassy, self-involved New York fashion plate-turned-charity founder who, along with three friends, finds himself entangled in the mysterious disappearance of a college classmate he barely knew. Watch a clip of Early in â€œSearch Partyâ€ and continue reading below.Even though Early has a field day delivering Elliottâ€™s cheeky one-liners and eye rolls, he sees the role as a departure from his previous work. â€œI like to play very nervous characters who canâ€™t string a sentence together, or who are always trying to control the moment, because itâ€™s very easy for me to access,â€ Early, who described himself as â€œvery nervousâ€ in his offscreen life, told The Huffington Post. â€œElliott is extremely confident, especially when heâ€™s around his friends. Heâ€™s not afraid to have a sour opinion about things, and I just found that extremely liberating â€” to play someone whoâ€™s not constantly trying to maintain a facade.â€It would be easy to dismiss the character as the showâ€™s comic relief â€” the tried-and-true, classic sitcom â€œgay sidekick,â€ if you will â€” in the first few episodes of â€œSearch Party.â€ But Elliottâ€™s dark side emerges in the showâ€™s final episodes, and the revelation is so deplorable, itâ€™s amazing that his boyfriend, Marc (played by Jeffery Self), and pals Dory (Alia Shawkat), Drew (John Reynolds) and Portia (Meredith Hagner) donâ€™t disown him on the spot.Acknowledging that Elliott â€œdoes some things that are purely for his image and not for the good of others,â€ Early sees the characterâ€™s less-than-savory attributes as a way of keeping him grounded in reality. â€œHe has this really great philosophy, which is that lying and playing dirty is the only way to exist in the world. Itâ€™s just a part of being alive,â€ he said. â€œIf you think you can be totally pure and totally good in your quest for meaning, then youâ€™re naive.â€With â€œSearch Partyâ€ riding a wave of buzz, Early hopes fans will also take the time to check out a lesser-known Netflix series, â€œThe Characters,â€ released in March. He wrote and starred in a â€œCharactersâ€ episode, and said itâ€™s the project heâ€™s most proud of to date. Having written his own stand-up material for years, he relished being involved behind the scenes as well as in front of the camera.Early told HuffPost he has no qualms about continuing to represent queer lives on stage and on screen. That dedication, in part, nabbed him a spot on this yearâ€™s the OUT 100, Out magazineâ€™s annual list of the 100 most compelling LGBTQ people in the world. And whether or not a second season of â€œSearch Partyâ€ gets the green light, however, Early vowed to â€œkeep daringâ€ himself moving forward. â€œAll I can do is stay true to my own sensibility,â€ he said, â€œand stay away from projects that I feel are not helpful to the queer community.â€Itâ€™s safe to say weâ€™ll be watching!

article: Will this pepper make vegetable chili dishes great again?A woman in southern England was slicing up a red bell pepper when she spotted what she said was the image of President-elect Donald Trump screaming straight back at her.â€œA discussion about Trump and the state of the world was going on while the veg was being sliced up,â€ Janet Ayers told The Register. â€œIt was as if the pepper was mirroring the conversation.â€Ayers posted a photograph of her curious find to Facebook on Nov. 26, and itâ€™s now setting the British media abuzz.Hereâ€™s how one of Ayersâ€™ Facebook friends reacted to the picture:After getting over the initial shock, Ayers said she continued chopping up the pepper and added it to the vegetable chili she was cooking at her home in Portsmouth.â€œWe ate it for dinner and suffered no ill effects from the Trump supper,â€ she told The Register. â€œWe are trying to carry on our lives as normal, after the incident, but may approach the next pepper with caution.â€The Huffington Post has reached out to Ayers for comment.

headline: An Easy Way To Understand Why Donald Trump Is Wrong About Climate Change
short descr: "When his son is 50 years old, if we don't do something now, it's going to be a very, very sad place for him."
image_caption(s): Fisher Stevens and Leonardo DiCaprio at the National Geographic screening of "Before The Flood"
article: â€œWhen we talk about climate change, people just tune out,â€ â€œBefore the Floodâ€ director Fisher Stevens told The Huffington Post over the phone, referring to producer Leonardo DiCaprioâ€™s stance on the climate change crisis.â€œBefore The Floodâ€ debuted just before the election in November to critical acclaim. But now, the documentary is even more necessary, given President-elect Donald Trumpâ€™s takes on global warming (hoax invented by the Chinese), the environmental Paris Agreement (bad deal) and his environmental-related cabinet positions (appointing and still considering climate change deniers).If youâ€™ve already seen a few climate change films or read articles about whatâ€™s happening, â€œBefore The Floodâ€ probably wonâ€™t do much in the way of surprising you about the dire state of the Earthâ€™s environment at the moment. Honorably, that wasnâ€™t the intention, as Stevens sacrificed the chance to make a groundbreaking documentary to instead make one that would educate those who havenâ€™t learned whatâ€™s going on yet.â€œWe werenâ€™t going after the people that watch climate change docs and already know all this stuff,â€ explained Stevens. â€œWe did want to change the mind of people that never would think about it and make them start caring. Make them understand how big this issue is and how important it is. And we wanted this [to be] for young people, kids in high school. Kids in college. That was really our goal.â€Due to DiCaprioâ€™s partnership in making this movie, compelling narratives conveying this important information became possibilities. Among numerous climate experts, â€œBefore The Floodâ€ features interviews with Secretary of State John Kerry, President Barack Obama and Pope Francis.Aside from his charisma and celebrity draw, Stevens insists DiCaprio was an invaluable partner in making sure this movie was actually educational. â€œI think when you see celebrities doing these movies with causes, often you feel like youâ€™re watching a puff piece,â€ said Stevens. â€œBut with Leo, he knew a lot [about climate change], heâ€™s passionate about it.â€Stevens also explained that DiCaprio had a pretty bleak view of the climateâ€™s chances before making â€œBefore the Flood,â€ but through his access to higher-level officials, the actor was persuaded into thinking we might be able to solve some problems.â€œHe had a much more pessimistic outlook,â€ Stevens said. â€œAnd you get to see Leo [in the movie] â€• and in real life this happened â€• he became much more optimistic.â€Of course, this optimism has been deflated by Trump winning the election, which Stevens expressed on the phone. Still, he wants to remain hopeful.â€œWhat we need to do is force Trump to put people in positions of power in terms of the head of the EPA, in terms of our Secretary of Energy, our Secretary of the Interior [and] our Attorney General. People that believe in climate change. And we are going to have to have a united front,â€ he said.Unfortunately, since our conversation, Trump announced his pick of Sen. Jeff Sessions (R-Ala.) for the Attorney General spot. Sessions is actually featured in the documentary for being a member of Congress that has been bad for the environment. Sessions is a climate change sceptic.â€œIâ€™ll tell you what Iâ€™m going to do. Iâ€™m going to do everything in my power to make this administration understand that climate change is real and itâ€™s urgent and itâ€™s happening now,â€ insisted Stevens. â€œRepublicans that believe in climate change â€• that can lead â€• those are the people Iâ€™m trying to get to. Thatâ€™s what we have to do, we all have to work together. Itâ€™s our planet.â€Recently, Trump has slightly retreated from his oppositional stances on trying to prevent climate change and perhaps there is still hope.â€œWhen his son [Barron Trump, 10] is 50 years old, if we donâ€™t do something now, itâ€™s going to be a very, very sad place for him,â€ said Stevens.If youâ€™ve been justifiably worried about what could happen to our environment under Trumpâ€™s presidency, and are unsure exactly what coming challenges will need the most work to solve, watching DiCaprio and Stevensâ€™ â€œBefore The Floodâ€ is an easy way to get involved.

headline: As Brazil Mourns The Chapecoense Plane Crash, Its Congress Guts Anti-Corruption Laws
short descr: â€œIn the dead of night, they took advantage of a moment of national mourning."
image_caption(s): Fans of the Chapecoense soccer club gathered to mourn the Monday plane crash that killed 71 people.
article: The lead prosecutor of a high-profile corruption case in Brazil is accusing the government of using the tragedy of a recent plane crash to sneakily pass a law that will protect dirty officials.On Tuesday, after a chartered flight carrying the Brazilian soccer club Chapecoense crashed in Colombia and killed 71 people on board, Brazil President Michel Temer declared a three-day period of national mourning.Hours later, the lower house of the Brazilian Congress overwhelmingly voted to gut an anti-corruption bill in a way that public prosecutors and political observers say could ensure lawmakers donâ€™t come under scrutiny.The original version of the proposed 10 Measures law sought to root out political corruption amid Brazilâ€™s ongoing Operation Car Wash money laundering investigation, which could ultimately implicate dozens of lawmakers for taking improper bribes from the state-owned oil giant Petrobras. The scandal, along with the September impeachment of former President Dilma Rousseff, has thrown the country into political crisis.But late on Tuesday night, Congress instead approved a version of the bill that included provisions allowing defendants to sue prosecutors and judges for overstepping their powers. The new version, which passed 450-1, also increases potential prison sentences for prosecutors and judges, a move prosecutors interpreted as an effort to put an end to Car Wash investigations and threaten the independence of the governmentâ€™s judicial branch.Deltan Dallagnol, one of the lead prosecutors in the Car Wash investigation, criticized the legislation in a Facebook post on Wednesday, saying that it â€œundermines the independence of the prosecution and the judiciary.â€When the plane carrying top Brazilian soccer club Chapecoense to the final of the Copa Sudamericana crashed in the mountains of Medellin, Colombia, late Monday night, it killed all but five on board. The sudden loss led to nationwide sadness. The upstart clubâ€™s Cinderella run to the final of South Americaâ€™s second-largest tournament had enraptured Brazilians.â€œIn the dead of night, [lawmakers] took advantage of a moment of national mourning and shock to subvert the proposals,â€ Dallagnol told The Guardian of the vote.Paulo Sotero, the director of the Brazil Initiative at the Woodrow Wilson International Center in Washington, also saw the maneuver as a cynical attempt to take advantage of the crash.â€œThese people will use anything and everything to try to save themselves,â€ Sotero, speaking from Sao Paulo, said. â€œPeople here are very hurt, and people are shocked. [Lawmakers] are probably trying to use the fact that people are very emotionally exposed here to try to pass this.â€The process in the lower house repeated itself Wednesday in the Brazilian Senate, but with a different outcome: Senate leader Renan Calheiros attempted to push the bill through in a late night vote, only to see it blocked. The Brazilian Supreme Court on Thursday voted that Calheiros should face trial for embezzlement, which he denies. The version of the bill approved in the lower house maintains some of the original anti-corruption measures. But it also removes rewards and protections for whistleblowers and amends the types of penalties lawmakers can face as a result of corruption, and the new, controversial elements undermine the original provisions, some observers said.â€œThe few points of the original proposal that remained are not enough to contain the major damage caused by inserting into the legislation intimidating measures against judges,â€ Marlon Reis, a judge and founder of the Movement to Combat Electoral Corruption, told HuffPost Brazil.Temer, who is facing growing unpopularity, has previously hinted that he will veto the package of reforms if it shields lawmakers from corruption probes. Top Brazilian public prosecutors, including those in charge of the Car Wash investigations, have threatened to resign en masse if the protection measures become law.â€œThe prosecutors of the Car Wash Task Force hereby express rejection of any attempt to terrorize attorneys, prosecutors and judges in their legitimate exercise of the research activity, processing and prosecution of crimes, especially those committed in the highest spheres of power,â€ Dallagnol wrote in his Facebook post.Rodrigo Maia, the president of Brazilâ€™s Congress, countered those arguments, telling reporters Wednesday that the process of revising the 10 Measures bill and legislating a new version of it was â€œvery transparent.â€Sotero, of the Wilson Center, said the lawmakersâ€™ attempt to force through changes to the anti-corruption bill has only strengthened Braziliansâ€™ resolve to carry through with the Car Wash investigation. He predicted that the efforts to amend the 10 Measures bill the way lawmakers hoped are finished. â€œThat legislation to water down Car Wash will not make progress. It is dead politically,â€ Sotero said. â€œThe judicial branch and the prosecutors have mobilized, and society is mobilized.â€â€œThe tolerance of impunity for people in high places is over,â€ he added. In another controversial move, Brazilâ€™s Senate on Tuesday approved a package of austerity measures aimed at reigning in federal spending.The measures, a Temer priority, would cap federal spending levels for 20 years, a move that could pose threats to public health, education and other social programs. Ahead of the vote, the possibility of austerity sparked massive protests from students and other opponents of the proposed caps across the capital city of Brasilia.The political turmoil has even begun to spill into Chapecoenseâ€™s weekend funeral ceremonies for the players who died.Temer is reportedly planning to skip the services out of apparent fear that disenchanted crowds will boo him. The president instead reportedly asked families of players who died to meet him at the airport so he could share his condolences, angering the father of at least one player.â€œNo, Iâ€™m not going to the airport,â€ said Osmar Machado, the father of defender Filipe Machado, who died in the crash. â€œHe has to come here. Do you think Iâ€™m going to leave my son here and go there to give him a hug, just because he is the president? Whatâ€™s the importance of giving him a hug. Itâ€™s even a lack of respect for him to stay there.â€HuffPost Brazilâ€™s Marcella Fernandes contributed reporting. This story has been updated with comments from Paulo Sotero and Osmar Machado.

headline: How D.C.'s Mayor Plans To End The HIV Epidemic In The Capitol's Backyard
short descr: The District is looking to reshape its public health landscape by 2020.
image_caption(s): From left to right, Dr. LaQuandra Nesbitt, Nancy Mahon, D.C. Mayor Muriel Bowser, Channing Wickham, Walter Smith and Michael Kharfen launched the 90/90/90/50 plan on Thursday.
article: More than 13,000 people are living with HIV in Washington, D.C. Thatâ€™s 2 percent of the cityâ€™s population, or double the rate that constitutes an â€œepidemicâ€ in the eyes of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Nancy Mahon, global executive director of the MAC AIDS Fund, the philanthropic arm of the cosmetic company MAC, says itâ€™s â€œshamefulâ€ that the infection rate is so high â€œin the backyard of our nationâ€™s Capitolâ€ â€• especially given the United Statesâ€™ leading role in funding international AIDS work. While D.C.â€™s infection rate has fallen from its height of 3 percent in 2009 â€• a rate that was higher than that of West Africa â€• the level of infection is still unacceptable, said D.C. Mayor Muriel Bowser at an event Thursday kicking off the cityâ€™s newest plan to combat the epidemic. Last year, Bowser and the cityâ€™s department of health announced that they would work with the Washington AIDS Partnership and the DC Appleseed Center for Law and Justice on an initiative to end the HIV epidemic in the District by 2020. The effort, they said, would be known as the 90/90/90/50 Plan.They outlined the details of that plan on Thursday, during an event scheduled to coincide with World AIDS Day. The plan stresses four goals: to ensure that 90 percent of D.C. residents living with HIV will know their status; that 90 percent of people diagnosed with HIV will be in treatment; that 90 percent of people in treatment will achieve viral load suppression; and that there will be a 50 percent decrease in new HIV infections, all by 2020.This plan builds on the 90-90-90 goals that UNAIDS, the United Nations organization committed to dealing with the disease, set out two years ago. D.C. joins New York state and San Francisco, which have set similar goals. Those places are leading the charge nationally, said Dr. Anthony Fauci, director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Disease. â€œThis plan is the kind of thing that leads to a tidal wave of cities trying to copy cities,â€ Fauci told The Huffington Post. â€œThe goal is that we should be striving for this worldwide, but if we can do this in the U.S. in high-level cities, this is a good step in the right direction.â€To achieve those goals, D.C. plans to build on the success of the cityâ€™s needle exchange program, which has reduced the number of new HIV cases among injection drug users by 95 percent since it was introduced in 2007. The cityâ€™s plans also include educational programs for health care providers, a push to reduce the stigma around the disease, and an effort to increase public awareness and accessibility of treatments like Pre-Exposure Prophylaxis, or PrEP â€• a drug regimen used to prevent infections among people who are at high risk for contracting HIV. It also calls for renewed efforts to make sure D.C. residents have access to stable housing, which the planâ€™s authors say is essential to overall wellness goals.The MAC AIDS Fund has also provided a $1 million grant for a marketing campaign to encourage D.C.â€™s black women to use PrEP. Black women are the second highest at-risk group in the district, accounting for 1 in 6 new HIV diagnoses.â€œI donâ€™t think itâ€™s any mistake that both the mayor and the director [of the D.C. Department of Health] are African-American women, and they are the first people in the country to do this,â€ Mahon said â€• a reference to Bowser and to DOHâ€™s Dr. LaQuandra Nesbitt.The MAC AIDS Fund has donated a total of $8.7 million to D.C. over the past decade. The latest grant is part of its $6.6 million initiative aimed at curbing HIV rates in cities around the globe, with campaigns in Paris, Berlin, Mexico City and London.Walter Smith, the executive director of DC Appleseed, a nonprofit organization dedicated to solving public policy problems in the nationâ€™s capital, said Thursday that the innovation in D.C.â€™s 90/90/90/50 Plan lies in its public and private partnerships, which he hopes can serve as an example for other cities.â€œGiven where we started, we came from a situation where the District of Columbia was setting a bad example for the nation â€• we all knew where we were with HIV/AIDS was absolutely unacceptable,â€ he said. â€œWe have come so far [from] that with this plan. We are on the verge of setting a good example for the nation.â€Fauci went even further in his praise.â€œThe dynamics of plans like this,â€ he said, â€œcan turn around outbreaks.â€

headline: Jill Steinâ€™s Recount Campaign Is Winning Her New Fame -- And Losing Her The Green Party
short descr: Party leaders are suspicious of their presidential nomineeâ€™s post-election strategy.
image_caption(s): Green Party presidential candidate Jill Stein has generated excitement -- and controversy -- with her campaign to recount votes in Wisconsin, Pennsylvania and Michigan.
article: WASHINGTON â€• Green Party presidential nominee Jill Steinâ€™s crowd-funded election recount is finally underway in Wisconsin â€• and it enjoys the cooperation of Hillary Clintonâ€™s presidential campaign. The recount is shaping up to be a huge source of media attention and fundraising for Stein, who barely registered on the national radar during the election. But, ironically, an initiative that has endeared Stein to some of the Democrats who once scorned her is upsetting many of the Green Party leaders who were her most loyal supporters. Mainly, they question Steinâ€™s choice of states and what they say is her willingness to work with â€• and serve the interests of â€• Democrats. Andrea Merida Cuellar, co-chair of the national Green Party, argues that recounts in states like Texas â€• where a Green Party railroad commissioner candidate narrowly missed the 5 percent threshold needed to secure the party 2018 ballot access â€• would have been more important for the party as a whole.â€œThis doesnâ€™t really help us in our party-building efforts, in state party building,â€ Merida said.Merida also believes the party should have higher priorities when it comes to restoring integrity to the voting process. She cites as an example the implementation of ranked choice voting, a process gaining traction in some states and cities.â€œWe have a whole slate of things we need to focus on to make sure that the next time somebody runs, we have a strong state party network to support that candidacy,â€ Merida said.Kevin Zeese, a senior adviser to Steinâ€™s campaign, longtime Green Party activist and former political candidate, echoed Meridaâ€™s sentiments.â€œThere are many other election integrity issues. A lot of them are at the registration and preventing people from voting levels that have a massive effect on the outcome,â€ Zeese said. Zeese also worries that recounts that simply reprocess the ballots through optical scanners or electronic voting machines, rather than recounting them manually, will not expose issues inherent in the electronic voting process.A Wisconsin judge ruled on Tuesday night that the Stein campaign could not compel Wisconsin counties to recount all ballots by hand. Forty-seven of the Badger Stateâ€™s 72 counties have nonetheless chosen to count them by hand, and an additional 13 counties will use a combination of manual counting and optical scanners.In Michigan, which uses only paper ballots counted by optical scanners, a pending recount will be done entirely by hand. But Zeese is discouraged by the level of Democratic Party involvement in that effort, which raises his doubts that it will be conducted with complete integrity.Mark Brewer, for example, an attorney Stein has hired to represent the recount effort in Michigan, is a former chairman of the Michigan Democratic Party.LuAnne Kozma, campaign director of the Committee to Ban Fracking in Michigan and a Green Party activist, pointed out several other Democratic Party-affiliated figures involved in the Michigan recount effort in a widely circulated email condemning the recount.â€œWe had a good crew of hard-working volunteers. We built the party,â€ Kozma wrote, referring to Green Party election efforts. â€œNow thisnews is devastating us and weâ€™ve been completely sidelined and blindsided.â€Even Steinâ€™s running mate, Ajamu Baraka, is opposed to the effort.â€œIt would be seen as carrying the water for the Democrats,â€ Baraka told CNN on Tuesday.Stein shocked the political world last week when she announced an effort to crowd-fund recounts in the closely fought battleground states of Wisconsin, Michigan and Pennsylvania. The Michigan recount was scheduled to begin Friday until the Trump campaign objected, arguing that, as a fourth-place finisher in the state, Stein cannot be considered â€œâ€˜aggrievedâ€™ by any alleged fraud or mistake.â€ The recount is now on hold, and Michiganâ€™s Board of State Canvassers will consider the objection on Friday. Meanwhile, in Pennsylvania, the Department of State is estimating that voters have petitioned for recounts in over 200 precincts in counties across the state. Counties, which have the discretion to accept these requests, are now assessing them.No candidate is legally entitled to finance a statewide recount in Pennsylvania unless they demonstrate that there was illegal activity in the way the election was conducted. The Stein campaign is contesting the Pennsylvania election with a lawsuit in Pennsylvaniaâ€™s Commonwealth Court and has a hearing scheduled for Monday morning.Although Stein faces accusations of suckering disgruntled Clinton voters to enhance her brand and raise funds for unrelated purposes, her decision to pick the three states that narrowly cost Clinton the election appears to have captured some Democratsâ€™ imaginations. Stein, who received no more than 1 percent of the vote in each of the three states, surprised many observers by shattering her $2 million fundraising goal within hours of launching the crowd-funding campaign last week.Stein has since increased its goal several times, citing Wisconsin state officialsâ€™ higher estimates of the cost of a recount and other unforeseen expenses. Thus far the campaign has raised $6.8 million of its latest $9.5 million goal. For its part, the Wisconsin Elections Commission maintains that its estimate of $3.5 million was its first real projection and that any previous figures put forward were based loosely on the cost of past recounts.Stein denies that the recount is about anything other than authenticating the results, however. â€œVerifying the vote through this recount is the only way to confirm that every vote has been counted securely and accurately and is not compromised by machine or human error, or by tampering or hacking,â€ Stein said in a statement. â€œThe recount does not benefit one candidate over another. It benefits all voters across the political spectrum. This is an essential first step to restore confidence in our elections and trust in our democracy.â€In the Wisconsin and Pennsylvania recount petitions, as grounds for concerns about electronic vote tampering, Stein cites the analysis of University of Michigan data scientist J. Alex Halderman and the hacking of emails from the Democratic National Committee and Clinton campaign chairman John Podesta. Stein also mentioned the disconnect between most pre-election polling and election results.The Stein campaignâ€™s press staff did not respond to requests for comment on the specific criticism of Green Party leaders.In addition to practical concerns with a recount seemingly tailored to solicit Democratic support, Steinâ€™s Green Party critics have ideological concerns about the collaboration with Democrats.For instance, the Wisconsin petition and Pennsylvania lawsuitâ€™s references to the possible involvement of the Russian government in election tampering due to its alleged role in the DNC and Podesta email hacks dismayed Merida. She believes the accusations against Russia have yet to be substantiated and are being used to ratchet up tensions between the two countries â€• something Stein stood against during her campaign.â€œThis is a candidate who was in Russia two years ago and was doing this because we are a party of peace,â€ Merida said. â€œFor her to now say the Russians did it because they supposedly hacked into DNC email servers â€• itâ€™s disconcerting to say the least.â€Both Zeese and Merida lament that Steinâ€™s campaign did not solicit the input of top Green Party officials before deciding to go forward. The campaign presented it to the Green Party steering committee as a â€œfait accompli,â€ according to Merida.â€œShe just did it unilaterally and didnâ€™t talk to people. She could have done New Hampshire or Maine â€• small, easy states â€• and then it wouldnâ€™t have been about Clinton,â€ Zeese said. Neither Zeese nor Merida was willing to question the genuineness of Steinâ€™s motives. But Merida made it clear that the future of the party should not be so tied to Steinâ€™s presidential campaign. â€œJill Stein is not the Green Party. She is simply a member of the Green Party,â€ Merida said. â€œAt this point after Election Day, we do have to recalibrate within the Green Party toward the Green Party and away from the Jill Stein campaign,â€ she added.

headline: National Health Care Spending Rose Faster Last Year Because More People Got Care
short descr: The Affordable Care Act's coverage expansion enabled people to get medical treatment, but at a cost.
image_caption(s): Arminda Murillo, 54, reads a leaflet on Obamacare at a health insurance enrollment event in Cudahy, California, on March 27, 2014.
article: WASHINGTON â€• Health care spending by U.S. households, businesses and the government rose almost 6 percent last year to $3.2 trillion, driven by the large expansion of health coverage brought about by the Affordable Care Act, federal auditors reported Friday.The good news is this means more Americans had health insurance or government health benefits and that they used them to receive medical care. The bad news is the uptick, which follows several years of historically low growth in health care spending, means health care made up an even larger share of the U.S. economy, reaching 17.8 percent in 2015, a 0.4 percentage point increase. The independent Office of the Actuary at the federal Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Service published the new data in the journal Health Affairs.Total national expenditures grew by 5.8 percent in 2015, the largest year-to-year increase since 2007, and 0.5 percentage points faster than in 2014, when the Affordable Care Actâ€™s expansion of coverage began. According to the Department of Health and Human Services, more than 20 million previously uninsured people have gained coverage from private health insurance or Medicaid since 2014, and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has reported the uninsured rate is at an all-time low.â€œOur significant progress in reducing the nationâ€™s uninsured rate, while providing strong protections for Americans if they get sick, would not be possible without the Affordable Care Act,â€ Andy Slavitt, acting CMS administrator, said in a press release. â€œAs millions more Americans have obtained health insurance, per-person cost growth remains at historically modest levels.â€From 2009 to 2013, health care spending rose at the lowest annual rates in the more than half-century that the actuaries have produced these annual reports, increasing an average of just 4 percent a year over that time. This followed decades of more rapid acceleration in health care spending that at times reached double digits per year.The consensus has been that this unusually slow growth was mainly a consequence of the Great Recession and slow recovery at the beginning of this decade. Historically, Americans spend less on health care during economic downturns because of job loss and lower income, and expenditures rebound when the economy improves.That pattern appears to have repeated itself, but President Barack Obamaâ€™s administration and some economists also believe the cost-containment provisions of the 2010 health care reform law contributed to the slowdown by encouraging efficiencies in the health care system, even as it ramped up spending on medical care for newly covered people. And the nation is spending less on health care than projected before Obama enacted the Affordable Care Act.The coverage expansion is reflected in the 2015 spending patterns. Expenditures on hospital care, physician and clinical services rose faster than during the prior year as people received more medical care. Prescription drug spending growth, by contrast, slowed compared to 2014. Notably, rising prices for medical services and products were less a factor in overall spending growth than was the increase in the amount and intensity of medical care people received in 2014 and 2015. That breaks with historical trends, when price hikes constituted a bigger share of the year-to-year growth.The results of the election make predicting future trends difficult. Prior to Donald Trumpâ€™s winning the White House and Republicansâ€™ maintaining control of Congress â€• putting them in position to repeal the Affordable Care Act and make other, sweeping changes to the health care system â€• the actuaries at the Medicare agency had projected that overall spending would rise by an average of 5.8 percent a year from 2015 to 2025, and that health care eventually would constitute one-fifth of gross domestic product. Doing away with the Affordable Care Act would dramatically change the equation. Eliminating the lawâ€™s Medicaid expansion, the subsidies it provides for private insurance and its guarantee of coverage for people with pre-existing conditions will shrink the insurance rolls and reduce costs for the federal government. But repeal also would do away with cost-containment policies, such as not paying hospitals to re-treat patients for the same condition if they must return within 30 days for more care. And some portion of the reduced federal spending will simply shift to individuals paying out of pocket for health care and to hospitals and others that will provide charity care and absorb unpaid bills.Trump and congressional Republicans also vow to devise a new health care agenda that will succeed the Affordable Care Act, but since they currently have no such plan â€• and may not for another three years â€• evaluating its effects on health care spending is problematic.

article: Demi Lovato is sending an encouraging message to anyone dealing with a mental health condition: Donâ€™t give up.The singer recently opened up to People magazine about her own experience with bipolar disorder and her recovery.â€œIf you know someone or if youâ€™re dealing with it yourself, just know that it is possible to live well,â€ Lovato said. â€œIâ€™m living proof of that.â€Lovato, who has been outspoken about her diagnosis for years, also talked about her involvement with the Be Vocal: Speak Up for Mental Health campaign, which was launched by several major mental health organizations in 2015.â€œThis partnership means a lot to my fans because so many of my fans are dealing with mental illness, whether itâ€™s depression or bipolar disorder or even schizophrenia,â€ Lovato told the publication. â€œI have fans that deal with all sorts of mental illnesses so this is very important to them.â€Approximately one in five American adults will experience a mental health issue at some point in his or her life. This often makes people avoid seeking treatment.Lovato hopes that by sharing her story she motivates her fans to seek support if theyâ€™re dealing with a mental illness.
