article: Michael â€œJimâ€ Delligatti, the inventor of McDonaldâ€™s iconic Big Mac sandwich, has died at age 98.The fast-food legend died Monday in Pittsburgh, the city where he opened his first McDonaldâ€™s franchise, McDonaldâ€™s spokesperson Becca Hary confirmed to The Huffington Post on Wednesday.Delligatti first introduced his seven-ingredient, triple-decker hamburger creation to customers at his Uniontown, Pennsylvania, location in 1967. The hefty sandwich â€• a combination of two all-beef patties, lettuce, cheese, pickles, onions and â€œsecret sauce,â€ all on a sesame seed bun â€• was officially added to the national menu in 1968. The sandwich is now available in over 100 countries. The company said it sold 550 million Big Macs in the U.S. alone in 2007, the last time the company reported that number.The businessman owned 47 McDonaldâ€™s locations in Pennsylvania, making him â€œone of the single largest franchise holders in the companyâ€™s history,â€ his family said.Delligatti will also be remembered for his significant contributions to charity. In 1979, he co-founded Pittsburghâ€™s Ronald McDonald House, which provides accommodations for families whose children are receiving medical care in the area.â€œWe will remember Jim as an insightful franchisee, a knowledgeable businessman, and an honorable gentleman who left a legacy of four generations of family members running great restaurants in Pennsylvania and North Carolina,â€ Hary told HuffPost in an email.So next time you scarf down a Big Mac meal, be sure to pour out some of your soft drink in Delligattiâ€™s honor.

headline: Reporter Sopan Deb Shifts From Chronicling Donald Trump To Covering Culture
short descr: A 2016 standout for CBS News heads to The New York Times.
image_caption(s): CBS News correspondent Sopan Deb describes getting arrested at a Trump rally.
article: NEW YORK â€• Sopan Deb, who emerged as a standout 2016 reporter for his tireless coverage of Donald Trump, is joining The New York Times culture desk. In a memo to staff, Times Culture Editor Danielle Mattoon said Deb will â€œcover a spectrum of news â€“ cultural, political, race/gender/class, way-we-live-now â€“ through arts and entertainment lenses in the Trump era.â€Deb, 28, joined CBS in 2014 as an associate producer following stints at NBC News, Al Jazeera Media Network, The Boston Globe and Major League Baseball. He became one of the networkâ€™s campaign digital journalists, or â€œembeds,â€ in June 2015, just as Trump entered the race.He followed the insurgent Republican candidate throughout the country for CBS News and even got arrested at one particularly raucous Chicago rally. But it was Debâ€™s Twitter feed, a rolling resource for Trump interview transcripts and fact-checks of the candidateâ€™s claims, that distinguished the journalist. When Politico recently named Deb one the â€œbreakout media starsâ€ of the election season, a television executive described the reporter as â€œAmericaâ€™s representative to the Trump campaignâ€ on account of his Twitter feed. The executive said that â€œevery single person is trying to hire him.â€In the memo internally announcing his hire, Mattoon cited Debâ€™s â€œambitious, multi-platform articles, videos, and innovative storytellingâ€ on the campaign trail, including his Twitter feed.â€œMost notably he pioneered a story form for fact-checking and analyzing Trump: Sopan transcribed the candidateâ€™s remarks at rallies, events, press conferences, and interviews, then highlighted key sections and words and offered spot analysis â€• posting it all relentlessly on Twitter,â€ she wrote. â€œWith this approach Sopan was able to shine a singular spotlight on the most newsworthy, surprising, and troubling parts of Trumpâ€™s message. He also put Trumpâ€™s language in context so even the candidate couldnâ€™t quibble.â€While moving to the culture desk may seem surprising given Debâ€™s Trump-obsessed Twitter feed, he has interests outside politics. Deb is a classical pianist, as well as a stand-up comedian. â€œSopanâ€™s superb reporting during this fast-paced and high-charged election cycle was second to none, and we at CBS are sad to see him go,â€ CBS News Washington Bureau Chief Chris Isham said in a quote in the memo.Isham added he has no doubt Deb â€œwill bring the same energy to his new beat.â€Read the full memo below:Iâ€™m thrilled to announce that Sopan Deb of the CBS News politics team will be joining Culture as a general news reporter.

headline: Kellyanne Conway To Visit Canada's Tar Sands, And That Can't Mean Anything Good
short descr: The trip has been called â€œa strong signal to Canadians on the importance of this province to the United States.â€
image_caption(s): Kellyanne Conway will visit Fort McMurray, Alberta, in January to see Canada's tar sands.
article: President-elect Donald Trumpâ€™s former campaign manager Kellyanne Conway will visit Canadaâ€™s tar sands early next year ahead of his inauguration. Itâ€™s a bad omen for the fight against climate change â€• and may portend renewed hope for the controversial Keystone XL pipeline â€• considering the president-elect has promised to ramp up fossil fuel production and spurned efforts to halt climate change.But Alberta Prosperity Fund chair Heather Forsyth hailed the move as â€œa strong signal to Canadians on the importance of this province to the United Statesâ€ when the super PAC announced the visit on Tuesday.â€œThis visit by such an influential member of a U.S. administration should stand as a call to action for all Alberta industry,â€ said Barry McNamar, founder and president of Alberta Prosperity Fund, in a statement. â€œI hope that Ms. Conway receives an enthusiastic welcome here in Alberta and can return to the U.S. with an informed attitude towards Canadian export products.â€The tar sands have been a contentious place in American politics ever since the Keystone pipeline was proposed. It would have carried up to 730,000 barrels of Canadian oil into the country a day, but President Barack Obama rejected the project last year after environmental groups raised concerns about how expensive and dirty the fuel is to produce.Refining oil from tar sands is water-intensive and usually involves the clearing of large swaths of land. The finished product also results in substantially higher greenhouse gas emissions than other means of crude production.While Obama said Keystone wouldnâ€™t â€œserve the national interest of the United States,â€ many are now looking to the incoming Trump administration to see if the president-elect plans to reconsider the pipeline. TransCanada, the company behind Keystone, said it planned to â€œengageâ€ with Trump shortly after his election and a spokesman said they remained â€œfully committed to buildingâ€ the pipeline. That sentiment was echoed by Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.), who has asked Trump to approve the pipeline should a proposal cross his desk.The Washington Post notes that Conwayâ€™s visit would â€œmake a powerful symbolic statement about where a Trump presidency might come down on the proposed Keystone XL pipeline that President Obama rejected but which would, if revived, link the oil sands region in Alberta to advanced refineries on the Texas gulf coast.â€However, even if Trump is amenable to tar sands, the price of crude oil has plummeted in recent years and the construction of Keystone may no longer be economically viable. Oil cost about $100 a barrel when the project was first proposed, but the price now hovers around $50.Canadaâ€™s Prime Minister Justin Trudeau approved two other tar sands pipelines on Tuesday, the Kinder-Morgan Trans Mountain and Enbridge Line 3, drawing sharp criticism from groups who said the decision contradicted pledges to mitigate climate change.â€œWeâ€™ve heard clearly from Canadians that they donâ€™t want to see someone trying to make a choice between whatâ€™s good for the environment and whatâ€™s good for the economy,â€ Trudeau said at a press conference.

headline: How Courts Could Force Cops To Get Serious About Using Body Cameras
short descr: Jurors should be told to question any police testimony involving incidents that should have been recorded but weren't, according to a new report.
image_caption(s): The proposed jury instructions for any case involving an incident that wasn't recorded by body cameras, but should have been.
article: It was Barine Deeziaâ€™s word against that of the Lincoln Police Department.Deezia, 36, sat in a Nebraska courtroom earlier this month and testified that he was not guilty of obstructing police or resisting arrest during a March incident in which officers threw him to the ground and broke his shoulder. A few minutes before the scuffle, they had approached Deezia and his friends to ask about a companion who appeared visibly intoxicated. Officers say Deezia interfered and ultimately resisted arrest when they returned to question his friend. But Deezia claims the police used excessive force on him when they smashed his face against a glass door and slammed him onto a brick walkway.Video evidence is supposed to provide an objective record of the facts when police, defendants and witnesses present opposing narratives of confrontations like this. Thatâ€™s just one reason body cameras have arisen as a rare point of agreement in the debate over police reform. But as the technology has grown in popularity around the U.S., cases like Deeziaâ€™s show why itâ€™s an imperfect solution for issues of transparency and accountability.The officers who arrested Deezia were equipped with body cameras, but police say they werenâ€™t activated during the incident. At least one body camera was turned on during an initial encounter with Deezia. However, it was off when the officers engaged with the group and the altercation escalated minutes later. The Lincoln Police Department released surveillance footage that appears to show a piece of the scene unfold, but also omits the key moment.With little evidence to go on, it took the jury only an hour to reach a verdict in Deeziaâ€™s case: not guilty on all charges. His excessive force lawsuit against the city is still pending.â€œWithout the body cameras, they couldnâ€™t take one personâ€™s word over the other,â€ Seth Morris, Deeziaâ€™s attorney, told The Huffington Post.The fact that the body camera hadnâ€™t been reactivated was a key point of concern for the jury, Morris said. Although the Lincoln Police Department hasnâ€™t crafted an official policy on using the cameras, Morris said it was suspicious that the officer had initially remembered to turn on the camera, only to forget later.â€œNo matter what did or didnâ€™t happen, it just seems like youâ€™re trying to hide something at that point,â€ he said.Still, it could have turned out much differently for Deezia. Jurors often arenâ€™t so skeptical of police. When asked to choose between a defendantâ€™s word and an officerâ€™s, many will simply side with law enforcement.As the American Civil Liberties Union of Massachusetts and University of California, Berkeley, School of Law argue in a report published Tuesday, this point further underscores just how important it is for police to use body cameras correctly. Such forms of monitoring are supposed to create an unbiased account of what was said and done by each party, which proponents say can keep officers and civilians honest.But as the devices have spread to police departments around the nation, there have been a number of incidents in which officers have failed to record critical incidents, including fatal shootings. Weak or nonexistent disciplinary rules for officers who fail to abide by body camera policies have compounded these problems.The ACLU/Berkeley Law report says courts at the state level should pressure police by instructing juries to disregard any testimony given by an officer deemed to have not recorded an incident or to have tampered with footage in a deliberate attempt to conceal the truth. If the jury were to conclude that an officerâ€™s failure to record was unreasonable â€• but not malicious â€• the court would instruct the jury to devalue that officerâ€™s testimony and infer that the video would have been beneficial to the defendant.â€œCourts have a special interest in ensuring that thereâ€™s footage available, because theyâ€™re the ones responsible for making sure juries reach accurate decisions and donâ€™t lock someone up who doesnâ€™t deserve to be there,â€ said Catherine Crump, acting director of the Samuelson Law, Technology & Public Policy Clinic at Berkeley Law and a co-author of the report.â€œIf they start imposing those types of consequences, police departments will take more seriously the risk that if you donâ€™t turn these things on, then youâ€™re not going to be able to achieve your law enforcement objective,â€ she added.Although body cameras are regularly touted as a way to keep tabs on police brutality and use of lethal force, theyâ€™re also essential in much more routine law enforcement activity.A client of Washington, D.C., defense attorney George Lyon was arrested earlier this year for allegedly having an open container of alcohol in public. She maintained her innocence and said she was arrested because she had an attitude with an officer. Lyon began to prepare a defense because the city was intent on proceeding with the case. When he requested body camera footage from the arresting officerâ€™s camera, he found that it showed the bottles in question were nowhere near his client. The prosecution eventually dropped all charges.Lyon said heâ€™d be highly skeptical if he were defending a case in which an officer couldnâ€™t provide a good explanation for a deactivated body camera.â€œIf the police officer doesnâ€™t turn on the camera or somehow the video is erased, I would argue that the jury should infer that the evidence that has been spoiled would have been favorable to a client,â€ he said. Under the proposal from the ACLU and Berkeley Law, courts would officially offer this guidance to juries.There is precedent for these sorts of jury instructions. In police interrogations, for example, officers used to be able to question suspects in custody without recording it. Now, over 20 states impose consequences for failing to record, often by instructing jurors to treat testimony with special caution in cases in which there is no video documentation of the interrogation.States like South Carolina have also passed statutes requiring officers to record audio and video of all DUI field sobriety tests. A failure to do so will typically lead courts to dismiss charges, as they view such oversights as fatal to most cases.â€œIf the footage shows someone stumbling around, itâ€™s hard for them to say that they werenâ€™t impaired under those circumstances,â€ Lyon said. â€œBy the same token, if they donâ€™t appear to be impaired, the camera evidence is gonna show that as well.â€Although courts may be able to help force the hand of police who have shown resistance to calls for change, theyâ€™re not a substitute for strong body camera policies designed to compel departments to commit to accountability and transparency. Still, in the current political climate, some legal experts believes it may take creative, unorthodox approaches like this to achieve certain policy goals.â€œGiven what happened in the last presidential election, we may need to look elsewhere for progress on things like police reform,â€ Crump said. â€œThis is a constructive effort to offer another way forward.â€ Clarification: Catherine Crumpâ€™s title has been updated to reflect that she is no longer with the ACLU.

headline: Trump Claims He's Leaving His Company 'In Total' â€” But Doesn't Provide Any Details
authors: Steve Holland and Doina Chiacu, Reuters
short descr: He says it's "visually important" to do so.
image_caption(s): President-elect Donald Trump may turn over his business to his children, which presents conflicts of interest in and of themselves.
article: President-elect Donald Trump said Wednesday heâ€™s leaving his business â€œin total,â€ but provided no details about who would take over.â€œWhile I am not mandated to do this under the law, I feel it is visually important, as President, to in no way have a conflict of interest with my various businesses. ... Hence, legal documents are being crafted which take me completely out of business operations. The Presidency is a far more important task!â€ Trump said in a series of tweets posted Wednesday morning.Trump said he would hold a news conference with his children on Dec. 15 to discuss the move away from his business.Itâ€™s unclear whether he intends to turn daily control of the Trump Organization over to his three oldest children â€• Donald Jr., Ivanka and Eric â€• to run the privately owned conglomerate, or set up a blind trust. In a blind trust, the owner of a business relinquishes management of the companyâ€™s assets to an independent party to avoid conflicts of interest in public office.Trumpâ€™s lawyer said this month that the three adult children would control the blind trust. But then the president-elect enlisted all three to serve on his presidential transition teamâ€™s executive committee. Ivanka, widely seen as one of Trumpâ€™s closest surrogates, sat in on a meeting with Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe and on a call with Argentine President Mauricio Macri, casting doubt over the blindness of any trust led by the 35-year-old. Transition team spokesman Sean Spicer said working through the details is taking time, but that Trump is keeping his promise of devoting his full attention to the presidency. â€œHeâ€™s always been very clear that he was going to turn over the business to his adult children to run the family business, and that transition is whatâ€™s occurring right now,â€ Spicer said. But when asked whether Trump intended to divest himself of ownership of his various properties or merely managerial control, Spicer said the president-elect would provide that information next month.â€œMr. Trump will walk through the details on the 15th of December. So stay tuned,â€ Spicer said.What Trump should do is appoint a truly independent trustee to sell his business and manage the trust while he is in office, periodically reporting only the value of the companyâ€™s assets, according to an op-ed by two former chief White House ethics lawyers under President George W. Bush and President Barack Obama.â€œA blind trust is defined by federal law as one in which a federal official selects an independent trustee (with no familial ties) who sells the officialâ€™s known assets and purchases investments unknown to the official,â€ Richard Painter and Norman Eisen wrote. â€œThat is what makes it blind.â€The nature of the Trump Organizationâ€™s business also makes it difficult to eliminate conflicts of interest in the White House. The company is largely a real estate and licensing company, with an empire of properties across the United States and a portfolio of buildings around the world that pay to brandish the Trump name. Trumpâ€™s companies operate in at least 20 countries, according to a hefty New York Times analysis published on Nov. 26.That makes it harder to erase conflicts of interest, or at least the perception of them. Trump may not oversee the day-to-day activities of his company, but a local official eager to curry favor with the White House could easily identify a Trump property to lodge in, host events at or fast-track for development.Itâ€™s already happening. Three days after Trump received a congratulatory call from Macri, a long-stalled tower in Buenos Aires got the green light from city officials. Both Trump and Macri denied reports that the incoming president asked for help clearing the permits to build the office tower. But itâ€™s hard not to be skeptical. On a call with Turkish President Recep Tayyip ErdoÄŸan, Trump touted his Turkish business partner as â€œa close friendâ€ and passed on remarks that he is â€œyour great admirer,â€ as The Huffington Post reported last week. The Embassy of Bahrain on Tuesday said it plans to host its annual National Day celebration at the newly opened Trump International Hotel in Washington, D.C., next month. The hotel became a flashpoint of the president-electâ€™s conflicts of interest when it suggested this month that foreign officials should stay there during official trips to help their relationship with the White House.Trumpâ€™s business interests represent an unprecedented web of conflicts of interest, particularly when compared to his predecessor. Obamaâ€™s assets, worth between $2 million and $7 million, are mostly tied up in Treasury bills and index funds. He and first lady Michelle Obama are still paying off a 30-year mortgage on their home in Chicago. S.V. Date contributed to this report. This article has been updated to include comment from Sean Spicer.

headline: Michigan Is Still Fighting A Court Order To Provide Water To Flint
short descr: â€œWeâ€™ve got an ongoing crisis to this day,â€ the Natural Resources Defense Council says.
image_caption(s): Michigan Gov. Rick Snyder testifies at a House Oversight and Government Reform hearing. Snyder is pushing back against a court order to provide bottled water to Flint residents.
article: Nearly three weeks after a federal judge ordered Michigan officials to deliver bottled water to Flint residents who lack access to safe drinking water, the state continues to fight it.The preliminary injunction, issued by U.S. District Judge David M. Lawson on Nov. 10, calls for state and city officials to deliver bottled water to all Flint homes unless residents decline it or it is otherwise verified that the home has a properly installed, functioning water filter.The state appealed that ruling in a Nov. 17 court motion, calling the ordered water distribution a â€œherculean effortâ€ that â€œwould be on the magnitude of a large-scale military operationâ€ and extremely costly. The state estimates it would cost at least $10.5 million monthly to carry out and is seeking an emergency motion to block the order.A ruling on the stateâ€™s motion is expected from the 6th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals any day now. Until then, state and city officials are required to file a status report on their compliance with the order by Dec. 16.In a Tuesday call, representatives of the Natural Resources Defense Council, which along with the American Civil Liberties Union is a plaintiff in the lawsuit, criticized the state of Michigan for â€œspending its time litigating as opposed to assuring safe water to its residents.â€The NRDC filed a brief Monday with the 6th Circuit describing the â€œharsh, on-the-ground realityâ€ of Flint residents who are still â€œstruggling to obtain enough safe water to meet their daily needs.â€ The organization is calling on the court to deny the stateâ€™s motion for a stay.â€œWeâ€™ve got an ongoing crisis to this day,â€ NRDC Midwest Director Henry Henderson said. â€œPeople do not have access to safe water. This is not consistent with what we expect to happen to residents of the United States of America.â€The brief, authored by NRDC attorney Sarah C. Tallman, argues that the cityâ€™s and stateâ€™s response to drop off water filters at homes and operate water distribution sites is leaving many people behind, particularly residents without cars, the elderly and sick, and those who lack the â€œtools, strength or know-how to properly install, use and maintain filters left at their doors.â€That situation, the brief continues, will only worsen as winter approaches and temperatures plunge.In response to the criticism, Anna Heaton, a spokeswoman for Republican Gov. Rick Snyder, asserted that the state is continuing to provide bottled water and filters to all Flint residents, â€œas we have been for months now, while also working on the plan for the massive logistics rollout needed to meet the orderâ€™s requirements.â€Heaton also noted that the state has teams made up of Flint residents hired using Department of Labor grants along with state workers who are going door-to-door to check that provided water filters have been properly installed and maintained by residents.The state previously emphasized that at least 96 percent of Flintâ€™s water customers have filters, so that would mean only about 4 percent of the cityâ€™s residents would require ongoing water delivery.Still, in a separate filing to the court Tuesday, attorneys for Flint joined the state in calling the district courtâ€™s injunction â€œoverbroadâ€ and noted that the city lacked the resources required to comply with it.State health officials are still urging Flint residents to drink the tap water only after it has been filtered to remove lead contamination that was first confirmed in September 2015 by Dr. Mona Hanna-Attisha, a pediatrician.Residents of Flint, a high-poverty, predominantly black city, had been complaining about the quality of their water soon after the city left the Detroit water system and switched its drinking water sources to the polluted, highly corrosive Flint River in April 2014.Since then, Gov. Snyder and President Barack Obama have declared states of emergency in Flint, and the city has begun the slow and expensive process of replacing its lead water service lines throughout the city. According to the city, a total of 260 homes through the end of October have either gotten new service lines or had their lead lines capped. In total, at least 30,000 Flint homes need service lines replace.Itâ€™s going to take a lot of money to make that happen, and Flint officials and activists alike are hopeful that federal assistance will play a key role.David Goldston, NRDCâ€™s director of government affairs, called on Tuesday for Congress to approve immediate funding to help the residents of Flint before the end of its lame-duck session.The Republican-controlled House of Representatives authorized up to $170 million in aid to address Flintâ€™s ongoing water crisis in late September, $50 million short of the level of funding the Senate proposed as part of the Water Resources Development Act both the House and Senate approved earlier this year.â€œCongress has done little but dither for the entire duration of the Flint crisis,â€ Goldston said. â€œThe Republican leadership finally said they would insure money went to Flint, so in the next week or two we will see if they fulfill that promise.â€House Speaker Paul Ryan (R-Wis.) said Tuesday that Flintâ€™s aid is on track to be approved â€œone way or anotherâ€ â€• either through the water act or as part of a broader stopgap spending measure â€• before yearâ€™s end.â€•â€•Joseph Erbentraut covers promising innovations and challenges in the areas of food and water. In addition, Erbentraut explores the evolving ways Americans are identifying and defining themselves. Follow Erbentraut on Twitter at @robojojo. Tips? Email joseph.erbentraut@huffingtonpost.com.

Lawson on Nov. 10, calls for state and city officials to deliver bottled water to all Flint homes unless residents decline it or it is otherwise verified that the home has a properly installed, functioning water filter.The state appealed that ruling in a Nov. 17 court motion, calling the ordered water distribution a â€œherculean effortâ€ that â€œwould be on the magnitude of a large-scale military operationâ€ and extremely costly. The state estimates it would cost at least $10.5 million monthly to carry out and is seeking an emergency motion to block the order.A ruling on the stateâ€™s motion is expected from the 6th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals any day now. Until then, state and city officials are required to file a status report on their compliance with the order by Dec. 16.In a Tuesday call, representatives of the Natural Resources Defense Council, which along with the American Civil Liberties Union is a plaintiff in the lawsuit, criticized the state of Michigan for â€œspending its time litigating as opposed to assuring safe water to its residents.â€The NRDC filed a brief Monday with the 6th Circuit describing the â€œharsh, on-the-ground realityâ€ of Flint residents who are still â€œstruggling to obtain enough safe water to meet their daily needs.â€ The organization is calling on the court to deny the stateâ€™s motion for a stay.â€œWeâ€™ve got an ongoing crisis to this day,â€ NRDC Midwest Director Henry Henderson said. â€œPeople do not have access to safe water. This is not consistent with what we expect to happen to residents of the United States of America.â€The brief, authored by NRDC attorney Sarah C. Tallman, argues that the cityâ€™s and stateâ€™s response to drop off water filters at homes and operate water distribution sites is leaving many people behind, particularly residents without cars, the elderly and sick, and those who lack the â€œtools, strength or know-how to properly install, use and maintain filters left at their doors.â€That situation, the brief continues, will only worsen as winter approaches and temperatures plunge.In response to the criticism, Anna Heaton, a spokeswoman for Republican Gov. Rick Snyder, asserted that the state is continuing to provide bottled water and filters to all Flint residents, â€œas we have been for months now, while also working on the plan for the massive logistics rollout needed to meet the orderâ€™s requirements.â€Heaton also noted that the state has teams made up of Flint residents hired using Department of Labor grants along with state workers who are going door-to-door to check that provided water filters have been properly installed and maintained by residents.The state previously emphasized that at least 96 percent of Flintâ€™s water customers have filters, so that would mean only about 4 percent of the cityâ€™s residents would require ongoing water delivery.Still, in a separate filing to the court Tuesday, attorneys for Flint joined the state in calling the district courtâ€™s injunction â€œoverbroadâ€ and noted that the city lacked the resources required to comply with it.State health officials are still urging Flint residents to drink the tap water only after it has been filtered to remove lead contamination that was first confirmed in September 2015 by Dr. Mona Hanna-Attisha, a pediatrician.Residents of Flint, a high-poverty, predominantly black city, had been complaining about the quality of their water soon after the city left the Detroit water system and switched its drinking water sources to the polluted, highly corrosive Flint River in April 2014.Since then, Gov. Snyder and President Barack Obama have declared states of emergency in Flint, and the city has begun the slow and expensive process of replacing its lead water service lines throughout the city. According to the city, a total of 260 homes through the end of October have either gotten new service lines or had their lead lines capped. In total, at least 30,000 Flint homes need service lines replace.Itâ€™s going to take a lot of money to make that happen, and Flint officials and activists alike are hopeful that federal assistance will play a key role.David Goldston, NRDCâ€™s director of government affairs, called on Tuesday for Congress to approve immediate funding to help the residents of Flint before the end of its lame-duck session.The Republican-controlled House of Representatives authorized up to $170 million in aid to address Flintâ€™s ongoing water crisis in late September, $50 million short of the level of funding the Senate proposed as part of the Water Resources Development Act both the House and Senate approved earlier this year.â€œCongress has done little but dither for the entire duration of the Flint crisis,â€ Goldston said. â€œThe Republican leadership finally said they would insure money went to Flint, so in the next week or two we will see if they fulfill that promise.â€House Speaker Paul Ryan (R-Wis.) said Tuesday that Flintâ€™s aid is on track to be approved â€œone way or anotherâ€ â€• either through the water act or as part of a broader stopgap spending measure â€• before yearâ€™s end.â€•â€•Joseph Erbentraut covers promising innovations and challenges in the areas of food and water. In addition, Erbentraut explores the evolving ways Americans are identifying and defining themselves. Follow Erbentraut on Twitter at @robojojo. Tips? Email joseph.erbentraut@huffingtonpost.com.

headline: Supreme Court Could Give Donald Trump Free Rein To Indefinitely Detain Immigrants
short descr: The justices will decide whether immigration laws, or the Constitution itself, prevent non-citizens from being detained for years on end.
image_caption(s): The last time the Supreme Court heard an immigration case, the justices split 4-to-4. That could happen again.
article: WASHINGTON â€• With the specter of Donald Trumpâ€™s administration looming, the Supreme Court on Wednesday appeared deeply torn over whether non-citizens who are detained for prolonged periods of time have a right to timely bail hearings that may secure their release.The president-electâ€™s name and his proposed policies to round up and deport millions were not brought up directly. But if the high court accepts the Obama administrationâ€™s argument that neither the Constitution nor current statutes guarantee this kind of relief to a wide class of foreign-born detainees, the stance is sure to govern how Trump handles immigration policy. Trump has bashed President Barack Obama for releasing immigrants from detention while they await their deportations.Justice Elena Kagan, who forcefully challenged the governmentâ€™s position in the case, known as Jennings v. Rodriguez, set the tone for how the courtâ€™s more liberal members might choose to rule in the case.â€œYou canâ€™t just lock people up without any finding of dangerousness, without any finding of flight risk, for an indefinite period of time, and not run into due process,â€ said Kagan, referring to the constitutional provision that forbids officials from depriving anyone, including non-citizens, of their liberty.There are â€œconstitutional boundsâ€ to keeping people in detention for more than six months without a chance to see a judge, she noted.â€œDonâ€™t you think due process would require some periodic review to ensure that these people are properly being held?â€ asked Justice Sonia Sotomayor, observing that many of those who are caught up in immigration detention for long stretches have lived in the United States â€œfor decades.â€â€œWhat makes it unconstitutional in my mind is the unreasonable delay of detention,â€ said Sotomayor.Alejandro Rodriguez, the lead plaintiff in the class-action case, is a lawful permanent resident of the U.S. who has lived here since he was an infant. He was detained for more than three years without a substantive hearing, as the government sought his deportation based on two minor offenses â€• misdemeanor drug possession when he was 24 and joyriding when he was 19. He challenged his detention and was eventually released, but the proceedings dragged on for seven years before an immigration judge canceled Rodriguezâ€™s deportation and allowed him to remain in the country. But plenty of others who arenâ€™t so lucky are still languishing in detention â€• including undocumented immigrants, asylum-seekers and people, like Rodriguez, who are legally in the country but subject to removal.The Supreme Courtâ€™s task is to determine whether the complex web of immigration statutes that apply to these different groups of non-citizens affords them an opportunity to see a judge and vouch for their release â€• or else whether the Constitution may grant them that right.The government is currently holding more than 40,000 people per day, and aiming to add capacity for 5,000 more who are going through removal proceedings or awaiting deportation. For many immigrants, the proceedings take years, particularly given the lengthy backlogs in immigration courts, where more than 520,000 cases are pending.And although Immigration and Customs Enforcement officials have the power to voluntarily release some immigrants, the agency is â€œessentially the jailer, said Ahilan Arulanantham of the ACLU of Southern California, who argued the case for Rodriguez and the class, which includes thousands of people. Immigrants should get a chance to go to a neutral party like an immigration judge as well, he said.â€œThis is a class of mostly unrepresented people,â€ Arulanantham said, stressing the practical barriers non-citizens would face if their only recourse was to litigate their release on their own. â€œEverybody in the class, in our view, is entitled to an inquiryâ€ by a judge, he said.Many of the members of the class ended up winning their cases, raising questions about whether their long-term detention was necessary in the first place. All members were detained at least 180 days during their pending deportation proceedings, and they spent an average of 404 days in detention. Nearly all of those initially detained at the border sought asylum and two-thirds were granted it, according to a brief supporting the ACLUâ€™s position. Those who sought relief from deportation won their cases at a rate five times higher than the detained immigrant population generally.When Justice Samuel Alito questioned whether such a broad class of immigrants should have been allowed at all, Ian Gershengorn, representing the Obama administration, complained that the move was improper because affected immigrants get a chance to appeal their removal individually.â€œThat one-size-fits-all approach is not the right way to do it,â€ Gershengorn said, suggesting that the law requires immigrants to challenge their detention individually in federal court. This drew a rejoinder from Kagan.â€œWouldnâ€™t it be better to set some guideposts that everybody in the country would know to follow rather than having one suit pop up here and one suit pop up here and another in another place and everybody would be treated differently?â€ Kagan asked. â€œThat does not seem like a good immigration system.â€If a definitive guidepost exists at all, a sweeping constitutional ruling in favor of immigrants might provide it. But the last time the Supreme Court handled an immigration case with constitutional implications, it deadlocked 4-to-4 â€• which is also a possibility this time around.Chief Justice John Roberts seemed inclined to avoid a constitutional ruling or even be too aggressive with the law as it now stands.â€œOur job is to read the statute, and if it presents â€• if itâ€™s unconstitutional, thatâ€™s our job,â€ Roberts said. â€œBut we canâ€™t just write a different statute because we think it would be more administrable.â€A decision in Jennings v. Rodriguez is expected sometime before the end of June.

headline: Bob Dylan Didn't Attend Nobel Prize Meet-And-Greet Hosted By President Obama
short descr: The saga continues.
image_caption(s): Bob Dylan was a no-show at yet another Nobel Prizeâ€“related event.
article: The story about Bob Dylan and his Nobel Prize is never-ending. Many thought the songwriter, who was awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature, would be in attendance at President Obamaâ€™s Wednesday meet-and-greet for American Nobel Prize winners at the White House, but instead he was a no-show. â€œUnfortunately, Bob Dylan will not be at the White House today. So everyone can relax,â€ White House press secretary Josh Earnest told reporters, according to The Hill. The outlet notes Earnest did not provide a reason for his absence.Since winning the award, Dylan has stayed pretty quiet. At first, he failed to acknowledge the award and The Swedish Academy (the organization that chooses the winner of the Nobel Prize in Literature) admitted he wasnâ€™t answering their phone calls. Then, the bio on Dylanâ€™s website was updated to include a note about the prize, but was since taken down. When Dylan did finally respond to the accolade, the 75-year-old musician told The Telegraph he would â€œabsolutelyâ€ attend the ceremony â€œif itâ€™s at all possible.â€â€œItâ€™s hard to believe,â€ Dylan said about receiving the award, adding it was â€œamazing, incredible. Whoever dreams about something like that?â€After plenty of speculation about whether or not heâ€™d actually show up to the Dec. 10 ceremony in Sweden where the prizes are awarded, the Swedish Academy confirmed the songwriter had â€œpre-existing commitmentsâ€ and would be unable to attend.Dylan must still give a Nobel lecture, though, within six months counting from the date of the ceremony. Donâ€™t think twice, Bob, just do it.

headline: Progressives Blast Donald Trump's Treasury Pick
short descr: Critics are calling out Steve Mnuchin's loyalty to Wall Street -- and accusing the president-elect of hypocrisy.
image_caption(s): Steven Mnuchin, President-elect Donald Trumpâ€™s choice for Treasury Secretary, arrives at Trump Tower on Nov. 30, 2016. Mnuchin has drawn liberal criticism.
article: Progressive lawmakers and groups eager to expose President-elect Donald Trump as a populist in name only have found fertile ground in Steve Mnuchin, Trumpâ€™s choice for Treasury secretary.Thanks to his professional record, Mnuchin, a former second-generation partner at Goldman Sachs and hedge fund founder, would likely draw liberal criticism regardless of the president who appointed him.Mnuchin and his partners took over troubled bank IndyMac in 2008, renaming it One West and ramping up home foreclosures with a disproportionate focus on the reverse mortgages typically held by elderly Americans. Civil rights groups have accused the bank of racially discriminatory lending and business practices.If confirmed, which is all but assured, Mnuchin stands to oversee the very financial sector from which he profited handsomely. Perhaps it is no surprise then that Mnuchin has promised to roll back portions of the Dodd-Frank Wall Street reform law. Mnuchinâ€™s history and positions would rankle Democrats in any year. But Mnuchin is not just any nominee: he is Trumpâ€™s. The president-elect ran as a champion of working Americans and slammed opponent Hillary Clinton for her ties to Wall Street.â€œPresident-elect Trump campaigned against big moneyâ€™s power in Washington and accused Wall Street and hedge funds of â€˜getting away with murder,â€™â€ Sen. Sherrod Brown (D-Ohio), the ranking member of the Senate Banking Committee said in a statement. â€œBut now he has picked a hedge-fund manager whose Wall Street ties couldnâ€™t run deeper to lead the Treasury Department, which is exactly what this election showed the American people donâ€™t want. This isnâ€™t draining the swamp â€• itâ€™s stocking it with alligators.â€Sen. Jeff Merkley (D-Ore.), another member of the Banking Committee, also emphasized the apparent inconsistency of the selection.â€œIf you want somebody to dismantle the protections for consumers heâ€™s just the guy to do it. But that is in fact the opposite of what Trump campaigned on,â€ Merkley said on CNBC on Wednesday. â€œThis is another broken promise from Donald Trump to â€˜drain the swampâ€™ in Washington and not the change hardworking people in Wisconsin voted for,â€ Sen. Tammy Baldwin (D-Wis.) said in a statement.Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.), widely considered Wall Streetâ€™s toughest foe in Congress, was perhaps the most unsparing in her criticism of Mnuchin, calling him â€œthe Forrest Gump of the financial crisis â€• he managed to participate in all the worst practices on Wall Street.â€â€œHis selection as Treasury Secretary should send shivers down the spine of every American who got hit hard by the financial crisis, and is the latest sign that Donald Trump has no intention of draining the swamp and every intention of running Washington to benefit himself and his rich buddies,â€ she said in a statement.Warren later issued a joint statement with Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.) condemning Mnuchinâ€™s nomination.â€œSteve Mnuchin, is just another Wall Street insider. That is not the type of change that Donald Trump promised to bring to Washington â€“ that is hypocrisy at its worst,â€ the senators said.The Progressive Campaign Change Committee, a liberal advocacy group, sounded a similar note in a statement condemning Mnuchin as â€œyet another out-of-touch billionaire who is more concerned with self-dealing for Wall Street than protecting Americans from the too big to fail banks.â€â€œTrumpâ€™s supporters did not vote for him to put a second-generation Goldman Sachs banker who made a fortune foreclosing on working familiesâ€™ homes in charge of the economy,â€ the organization said.National Consumer Law Center attorney Alys Cohen focused her statement on Mnuchinâ€™s record of â€œprofiting by foreclosing on older homeowners and homeowners in communities of color.â€â€œWe call on Mr. Mnuchin, if confirmed, to use his leadership to help Main Street recover from the economic crisis caused by Wall Street, not to benefit the 1%,â€ Cohen said.Mnuchinâ€™s confirmation is virtually a foregone conclusion since he has aroused no public opposition from the Republican senators whose lack of support would jeopardize his nomination.But seeing a fight over Mnuchin as a long-term organizing tool, at least one liberal group, Demand Progress, is admonishing Democratic lawmakers to vote him down.â€œAs Democrats work to re-establish their partyâ€™s credibility as a voice for working people, not one Senate Democrat should vote to confirm Wall Street billionaire Steven Mnuchin for Treasury Secretary,â€ Demand Progressâ€™ Kurt Walters said in a statement.

headline: Drag Icon Charles Busch Sings A 'Muppets' Classic On His New Album
short descr: The star will return to the cabaret stage on New Year's Eve.
image_caption(s): Drag icon, actor and playwright Charles Busch is capping off 2016 with a new album and cabaret show.
article: Charles Busch put a heartfelt spin on â€œThe Rainbow Connectionâ€ as part of his new live album, and The Huffington Post has an exclusive first listen.The award-winning drag icon, actor and playwright tackled the song, which was introduced in 1979â€™s â€œThe Muppet Movie,â€ as part of his June cabaret engagement at New Yorkâ€™s Feinsteinâ€™s/54 Below. That evening was captured for posterity on Buschâ€™s album, â€œLive at Feinsteinâ€™s/54 Below,â€ which hits retailers Dec. 2.Despite the 62-year-oldâ€™s extensive rÃ©sumÃ© comprising stage, screen and cabaret credits, this is his first album â€” and he couldnâ€™t be more thrilled with the results.â€œI canâ€™t believe that I actually have a record out that Iâ€™m very, very proud of,â€ Busch told The Huffington Post. â€œI think itâ€™s a very good representation of who I am, and where I am right now.â€Just weeks after the albumâ€™s release, Busch will return to the Feinsteinâ€™s/54 stage Below for a special New Yearâ€™s Eve performance. That show will feature much of the same material as the album, he said, along with a few additional surprises.Busch told HuffPost that heâ€™s aware that his show will cap off whatâ€™s been an incredibly difficult year for many, including those in the LGBTQ community, and as a result, he is planning to conclude the show on an optimistic, forward-thinking note.â€œI would suspect that my audience tends to be on my political wavelength, butâ€¦ you never know,â€ he said. â€œItâ€™s not really a place for me to be pontificating. But, at the same time, New Yearâ€™s Eve is a very profound moment every year.â€Although Busch is tight-lipped on the specifics, heâ€™d be remiss if he didnâ€™t wear something fabulous in honor of the occasion, too. â€œFloating chiffon is good if youâ€™re over 40,â€ he quipped.Charles Buschâ€™s â€œLive at Feinsteinâ€™s/54 Belowâ€ will be released Dec. 2. He returns to Feinsteinâ€™s/54 Below on New Yearâ€™s Eve. For more information, head here.

headline: Mitt Romney After Donald Trump Dinner: He Can 'Lead Us To That Better Future'
short descr: Romney, Trump and Reince Priebus dined on frog legs at a French restaurant at one of Trump's hotels.
image_caption(s): Romney, Trump and Reince Priebus dined on frog legs, scallops, steak and lamb chop at a French restaurant at one of Trump's hotels.
article: NEW YORK, Nov 29 - Republican Mitt Romney made an impassioned statement in support of President-elect Donald Trump on Tuesday to try to erase doubts about him among Trumpâ€™s supporters and remain in contention for U.S. secretary of state.Romney, a fierce critic of Trump during the Republican presidential primary battle, stopped short of an outright apology but his intention to wipe the slate clean was clear.The former Massachusetts governor, who was the Republican presidential nominee in 2012 and lost, praised Trump for a â€œmessage of inclusion and bringing people togetherâ€ since his Nov. 8 victory over Democrat Hillary Clinton.Noting the appointments Trump has made to fill key cabinet positions for his administration and his desire for greater unity among Americans, Romney said that â€œall of those things combined give me increasing hope that President-elect Trump is the very man who can lead usâ€ to a better future.Romney made his remarks after a lengthy meal with Trump and Republican National Committee Chairman Reince Priebus at a French restaurant at a Trump hotel in Manhattan. They dined on garlic soup with frog legs, scallops, steak and lamb chop.Prior to Trumpâ€™s election win, Romney was a harsh critic of Trump.â€œDonald Trump is a phony, a fraud. His promises are as worthless as a degree from Trump University. Heâ€™s playing the members of the American public for suckers. He gets a free ride to the White House, and all we get is a lousy hat,â€ Romney said in March.Since Trump began to seriously consider Romney as a potential secretary of state, some on Trumpâ€™s team have voiced doubts about bringing in a former critic and rallied around their preferred candidate, former New York Mayor Rudy Giuliani, a long-time Trump friend and loyalist.Leading this effort in an unusually public way has been senior Trump adviser Kellyanne Conway, who told a round of television interviews on Sunday that Trump supporters would feel â€œbetrayedâ€ if Romney was picked.Trump, however, has kept Romney in contention for the secretary of state position, and a Republican source close to the transition effort said Priebus has been pushing for Romney behind the scenes.â€œI had a wonderful evening with President-elect Trump,â€ Romney said in remarks to reporters after the dinner. â€œWe had another discussion about affairs throughout the world and these discussions Iâ€™ve had with him have been enlightening, and interesting, and engaging. Iâ€™ve enjoyed them very, very much.â€Trump is also considering U.S. Senator Bob Corker of Tennessee, who is chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.Corker met Trump at Trump Tower earlier on Tuesday and told reporters afterward that Trump â€œneeds to choose someone that heâ€™s very comfortable with and he knows thereâ€™s going be no daylight between him and them.â€â€œThe world needs to know that the secretary of state is someone who speaks fully for the president and again, thatâ€™s a decision heâ€™s going to have to make,â€ Corker said.(Reporting by Steve Holland; Editing by Nick Macfie)

headline: Ethics Agency Trolls Donald Trump With Bizarre Tweets
short descr: â€œBrilliant! Divestiture is good for you, very good for America!â€  the Office of Government Ethics tweeted.
image_caption(s): Donald Trump with his children Donald Trump Jr. and Ivanka Trump at the Republican National Convention on July 20, 2016.
article: WASHINGTON â€• The Office of Government Ethics released a stream of odd tweets on Wednesday that praise President-elect Donald Trumpâ€™s plan to hand control of his real estate empire to his three eldest children.It was a very strange use of Twitter by a government agency.â€œWe canâ€™t repeat enough how good this total divestiture will be,â€ read the first tweet from the main ethics agency overseeing the executive branch.Earlier, Trump had tweeted that he was leaving his â€œgreat business in totalâ€ to his children Donald Jr., Ivanka and Eric Trump, following promises to hand them control of his Trump Organization and its subsidiaries after winning the presidential election.Yet he has never stated that he would completely divest from the business, liquidate its assets and put them in a blind trust â€• which would actually alleviate concerns about conflicts of interest.Still, the OGE appears to be framing Trumpâ€™s decision to consciously uncouple from his business as a â€œtotal divestitureâ€ that does â€œwhat handing over control could never have done.â€Because Trump did not explicitly mention divestiture, which would involve selling his business, itâ€™s possible the tweets were meant sarcastically, as a way to force the president-elect to engage with the agency or admit that he has no actual intention of divesting.Some of the OGEâ€™s tweets appear to mimic the prose style of the president-elect: â€œBrilliant! Divestiture is good for you, very good for America!â€ The agency also echoes Trumpâ€™s vague claim about leaving his business â€œin totalâ€: One tweet hinted at conversations the agency has had with Trumpâ€™s lawyers: â€œWe told your counsel weâ€™d sing your praises if you divested, we meant it.â€Similar tweets sent from the account Wednesday morning were subsequently deleted, causing speculation they were the work of a hacker or a rogue employee. The tweets were re-sent in the afternoon, however. A statement from the agencyâ€™s spokesman, Seth Jaffe, confirmed that the agency meant to send them.â€œLike everyone else, we were excited this morning to read the President-electâ€™s Twitter feed indicating that he wants to be free of conflicts of interest,â€ the statement reads. â€œOGE applauds that goal, which is consistent with an opinion OGE issued in 1983. Divestiture resolves conflicts of interest in a way that transferring control does not. We donâ€™t know the details of their plan, but we are willing and eager to help them with it.â€â€œThe tweets that OGE posted today were responding only to the public statement that the President-elect made on his Twitter feed about his plans regarding conflicts of interest. OGEâ€™s tweets were not based on any information about the President-electâ€™s plans beyond what was shared on his Twitter feed. OGE is non-partisan and does not endorse any individual.â€

headline: These Teen Boxers Show Us All The Real Meaning Of Sportswomanship
short descr: A Muslim boxer wasnâ€™t allowed to fight in modest clothing. So her opponent shared the win.
image_caption(s): Aliyah Charbonier (left) wears a scarf to show solidarity with Amaiya Zafar.
article: Amaiya Zafar is a 16-year-old amateur boxer from St. Paul, Minnesota, who has never gotten the chance to fight in an official competition. Sheâ€™s a Muslim who wears a hijab and covers her arms and legs while fighting â€• which isnâ€™t approved by international boxing regulations â€• so sheâ€™s usually banned from the ring before her matches even begin.
